questions.text: A radiologist is worried about the effects of her job involving radiation on the prenatal uterine development of her baby. In which one of the following periods is the fetus most susceptible to influences of the environment that could result in the occurrence of non-lethal congenital abnormalities?

choices.text: 1 week of fetal life to the 2nd week

questions.solution:
• The exposure of the fetus to environmental influences that could be harmful (teratogens), for example viruses, chemicals, radiation, etc, can happen at any time.
  • In the 3rd week to the 8th week of fetal life, the development of organ systems are in process and are most susceptible to such teratogenic influences.
  • Exposure in first 2 weeks- Spontaneous abortion
  • Exposure after 8th week - Organ growth retardation, no new structural or functional changes

questions.text: A 50 year old man, who has a habit of drinking six cans of beer a day and an increased intake on 'special days' and holidays presents to the OPD for a routine checkup. On investigation, an abnormal plasma lipoprotein profile is found. Erythrocyte fluidity is changed in liver disease, which explains this finding. Which one of the following would increase this membrane fluidity in this man's liver hepatocytes?

choices.text: The binding of an antibody to a receptor on the cell surface
Transmembrane lipid bilayer movement of phospholipids
Raised cholesterol to phospholipids ratio of the plasma membrane
The binding of cytoskeleton elements with integral membrane proteins

questions.solution:
• Cirrhosis of the liver causes changes in the plasma lipoproteins.
  • The binding of an antibody to a receptor on the cell surface causes the lateral diffusion of protein in the phospholipid bilayer, causing increased membrane fluidity - patching and capping.

questions.text: There is a linkage in the intermediate filament network of cells to the lamina basale. This linkage is done by:
questions.solution:
• Hemidesmosomes interact with extracellular matrix proteins through intermediate filamentous proteins.
  • When hemidesmosomes are combined with desmosomes, they act together to distribute tensile forces through the epithelial surface and the surrounding supporting connective tissues.

questions.text: A loss-of-function mutation in integrin expression on the lymphocytes causes certain disorders. These disorders would most likely result in which of the following?
questions.solution: A mutation resulting in loss of integrin function would prevent leukocytes from extravasting from the blood to the lymph nodes and sites of inflammation result- ing in increased lymphocytes in the blood (leukocytosis), not leukopenia.

questions.text: Which of the following inhalational anesthetics accumulates in air-filled cavities during general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
• Nitrous oxide: low solubility compared to other inhalation anesthetics.
  • Blood:gas partition coefficient: 0.47
  • 30 times more soluble in blood than nitrogen (N2).
  • The only anesthetic gas which is less dense than air.
  • Hence, N2O may cause progressive distention of air- filled spaces during prolonged anesthesia.
  • Whenever there is a pneumothorax, intestinal obstruction or procedures like pneumoventriculography, N2O diffuses into the gas-filled compartment faster than N2 can diffuse out. The typical mixture of ingested air is 80% N2 and the usual mixture of nitrous oxide anesthetic gas is 80% N2O, there is a rapid increase in the size of gas-filled chambers with potentially serious consequences may occur

questions.text: A man, 60 years old, presented with lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, fever, night sweats and loss of weight. BMA and biopsy were recommended. Which one of the following is the best place for a bone marrow sampling in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Patient appears to be suffering from CLL.
  • Iliac crest - best location for a sample in a BMA
  • Sternum - unsafe due to possible damage to thoracic structures
  • Long bones (humerus, tibia) have hematopoiesis during development, but they become dominated by adipose containing yellow marrow.

questions.text: Which statement regarding local anesthetics is true?

choices.text: When used for infiltration anesthesia, the maximal safe total dose of lidocaine is 3.0 mg per kilogram of body weight
Addition of epinephrine to solutions of lidocaine, procaine, or bupivacaine does not increase the maximal safe total dose but increases the duration of the block
Numerous individuals are hyper- sensitive to local anesthetics
Rapid systemic administration of local anesthetics may cause death without signs of CNS stimulation

questions.solution:
• Small nerve fibers appear to be most susceptible to the action of local anesthetics.
  • However, these agents act on any part of the nervous system and on every type of nerve fiber.
  • CNS toxicity: appears as stimulation --> followed by depression, possibly due to an early selective depression of inhibitory neurons. All neurons may be depressed simultaneously in a massive overdose.

questions.text: There exists a minimal blood-air barrier in the lungs. Which one of the following is a part of this pulmonary barrier?

choices.text: Fusion of basal laminae of endothelial and epithelial cells

questions.solution:
• O2 moves from alveolar air to blood in the capillaries, CO2 diffuses in the opposite direction --> They pass through a 3-component blood-air barrier.
  • This barrier consists:

-- Type I Pneumocytes

-- Endothelial cells

-- Fused basal laminae

  • The pores of Kohn: connections between one alveolus to the other; macrophages travel through these passages.

questions.text: Critically-ill patients warrant the frequent use of dopamine, because:

choices.text: It increases splanchnic flow, at high doses
It increases coronary flow, at high doses
It decreases heart rate, at low doses
It lowers peripheral resistance, at low doses

questions.solution:
• At low doses (1–5 mg/kg/min), dopamine affects dopaminergic receptors.
  • Activation of dopaminergic receptors causes:

-- vasodilation of the renal and mesenteric vasculature

-- mild vasoconstriction of the peripheral bed

-- redirects blood flow to kidneys and bowel.

  • As the dose rises (2–10 mg/kg/min), there is predominance of β1-receptor activity and the inotropic effect on the myocardium leads to raised cardiac output and blood pressure.
  • Above 10 mg/kg/min, α-receptor stimulation causes peripheral vasoconstriction, shifting of blood from extremities to organs, decreased kidney function, and hypertension. At all doses, the diastolic blood pressure can be expected to increase; as coronary perfusion is largely a due to the head of pressure at the coronary ostia, coronary blood flow should be increased

questions.text: Which one of the following is true for both he cells comprising the enteric nervous system of the gut and the enteroendocrine cells?

choices.text: Both are derived from neural crest
Both are found only in small intestine

questions.solution:
• The enteric nervous system and enteroendocrine cells secrete similar peptides.
  • They are found throughout the GIT.
  • Enteroendocrine cells: derived from the same stem cell as other epithelial cell types; and they originate from endoderm; they turn over slower than other epithelial cells.
  • The cells composing the enteric nervous system are neurons, derived from neural crest.

questions.text: A 21-year-old paraplegic patient is given succinylcholine, during intubation. The patient appears to demonstrate fasciculations, the vocal cords are easily visualized with a laryngoscope with the subsequent placement of the ET tube. Peaked T waves and intermittent ectopy are noted on the ECG. What is the most appropriate first step in this patient's management?
questions.solution:
• Calcium plays a cardioprotective role in the event of hyperkalemia by preventing life-threatening arrhythmias.
  • Additionally, hyperventilation can be started immediately if the patient is intubated because the respiratory alkalosis will lower serum potassium.
  • The other agents in the options are also administered as quickly as possible to decrease serum potassium. However, none of them provide the immediate cardioprotective effect seen with calcium.

questions.text: During re-epithelialization, naturally occurring, nonpathologic cervical erosions are usually corrected. In which one of the following reproductive classes of women are these erosions most common?
questions.solution:
• The uterine cervical stroma alters during each reproductive cycle.
  • During pregnancy and parturition, there is a 'thinning' of this stroma.
  • This results in multiple sites of exposed uterine columnar epithelium in the acidic, vaginal milieu, known as 'erosions'/ 'eversions'.
  • There is re-epithelialization in the form of squamous metaplasia at these sites, and they are hence perceived to be locations of cancerous transformation in the cervix.
  • Nabothian cysts are formed when the openings of cervical mucous glands are obliterated during this process of re-epithelialization.

questions.text: A tumor in the infratemporal fossa may gain entrance to the orbit through which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The infratemporal fossa communicates directly with the orbit via the inferior orbital fissure and the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • The fissure normally carries branches of the maxillary nerve (V2) and branches of the infraorbital vessels.
  • The optic canal and superior orbital fissure open into the middle cranial fossa and carry the optic nerve (CN II) and the oculomotor (CN III), trochlear (CN IV), and abducent (CN VI) nerves, respectively.
  • The pterygoid canal connects the middle cranial fossa with the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • The Vidian nerve traverses the pterygold canal on its way to the pterygopalatine ganglion.
  • The ethmoidal sinuses are mucosa-lined cavities within the ethmoid and adjacent bones. They drain into the nasal cavity.

questions.text: Which one of the folliowing is involved in pain that is referred to the right side of the neck and extends laterally from the right clavicle to the tip of the right shoulder?
questions.solution:
• The phrenic nerve, which arises from cervical nerves C3 through C5, mediates sensation from the diaphragmatic pleura and peritoneum, as well as from the pericardium; in addition, it carries motor fibers to the diaphragm.
  • Therefore, pain from the diaphragmatic pleura or peritoneum, as well as from the parietal pericardium, may be referred to dermatomes between C3 and C5, inclusive.
  • Those dermatomes correspond to the clavicular region and the anterior and lateral neck, as well as to the anterior, lateral, and posterior aspects of the shoulder.
  • Cervical cardiac accelerator nerves would be sympathetic, generally from T1-5.
  • The vagus which is a cranial nerve does not carry referred pain back to the brain.
  • The right intercostal nerve may carry referred pain from the parietal pleura to the chest wall.
  • The right recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus and does not carry referred pain to the brain.

questions.text: A 14 year old girl is hospitalized for evaluation of a possible seizure disorder because she has staring spells, lethargy, and irritability twice/ day. A 24-hour EEG shows diffuse epileptic foci that develop 4-6 hours after feeding, and low serum glucose is noted during these periods. Of the following dietary supplements, which might help this child?
questions.solution:
• Hypoglycemia during fasting is suggestive of a disorder of gluconeogenesis.
  • Gluconeogenesis involves the enzymes to reverse the reaction steps in glycolysis.

— pyruvatecarboxylase — phosphoenolpyruvatecarboxykinase

— fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase

— glucose-6-phosphatase

  • Pyruvate carboxylase: catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate and requires biotin with activation by acetyl-CoA.
  • Biotin is a cofactor in several carboxylation reactions.
  • Niacin is a source for NAD and NADH reactions

questions.text: A 22 year old male consults a physician because his father and a paternal aunt developed colon cancer in their mid-20s. Neither relative had multiple colonic polyps, so a diagnosis of HNPCC is considered. Many gene regions in HNPCC contain abnormal, small loops of unpaired DNA. These small DNA loops are the result of a mutation affecting which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Most HNPCC cases are associated with mutations of either of two genes that encode proteins critical in the surveillance of mismatches.
  • Mismatches are due to copying errors leading to one- to five-base unmatched pieces of DNA.
  • Two- to five-base- long unmatched bases form mini loops.
  • In normal conditions, specific proteins survey the newly formed DNA between adenine methylated bases within a GATC sequence.
  • Mismatches are removed and replaced.
  • Initially, a GATC endonuclease cuts the faulty strand at a site complementary to GATC.
  • Next, an exonuclease digests the strand from the GATC site beyond the mutation.
  • Finally, the excised faulty DNA is replaced. In HNPCC, the unrecognized mismatches accumulate, which leads to malignant growth of colon epithelium.

questions.text: High-energy phosphate-bond equivalents are utilized in the process of activation of amino acids for protein synthesis. Choose the number of these bond equivalents?
questions.solution:
• ATP is required for the esterification of amino acids to their corresponding tRNAs.
  • This is catalyzed by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases.
  • Each one of these enzymes is specific for one tRNA and its corresponding amino acid:

— amino acid + tRNA + ATP → aminoacyl-tRNA + AMP + PPi

  • As with most ATP hydrolysis reactions that release pyrophosphate, pyro-phosphatase quickly hydrolyzes the product to Pi, which makes the reaction irreversible.
  • Since ATP is hydrolyzed to AMP and PPi during the reaction, the equivalent of two high-energy phosphate bonds is utilized

questions.text: A 30 year old patient recently underwent a surgery and postoperative recovery which resulted in the compression of the peroneal nerve against the fibular head. This compression would result in which of the following motor deficits?

choices.text: Loss of flexion at the knee
Loss of medial rotation of the tibia

questions.solution:
• Compression of the common fibular (peroneal) nerve affects all muscles innervated by this nerve. This includes:

-- tibialis anterior

-- peroneuslongus

-- extensor digitorum longus.

  • Loss of dorsiflexion and eversion is usually absolute.
  • Extensors of the knee joint [quadriceps femoris]: supplied by the femoral nerve
  • Flexors of the knee joint [hamstrings and gracilis]: supplied by the tibial nerve and obturator nerve, respectively.
  • Gastrocnemius and soleus muscles: principal plantar flexors of the foot and are innervated by the tibial nerve.
  • Popliteus is the prime medial rotator of the tibia and is also innervated by the tibial nerve.

questions.text: What is the probable inheritance pattern in a family with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) where restriction analysis using sites flanking the CMT gene on chromosome 17 yields one large abnormal fragment and one smaller fragment that is seen in controls?
questions.solution:
• There are two DNA fragment sizes in the affected individual but one in controls, which suggests alteration of only one of the two homologous CMT regions on chromosome 17.
  • The production of disease by alteration of one homologous locus (one abnormal allele) causes autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • This form of CMT is caused by a duplication of the PMP22 gene, a gene which encodes a peripheral myelin protein.
  • This extra copy of PMP22 increases protein abundance and interferes with nerve conduction.
  • DNA duplication is one form of atypical inheritance discovered through DNA analysis

questions.text: A 13 year old girl presented to the OPD with tremors. On examination, she was found to have golden brown discoloration of the Descemet’s membrane. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Deposition of Cu in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea in Wilson's disease gives rise to the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring.
  • It first appears close to the superior Iimbus.

questions.text: A patient, with a history of a hyper mature cataract, presented to the ER with a sudden onset left eye pain. He appeared to have redness and photophobia in the left eye. There was increased IOP in a deep anterior chamber in the left eye. The right eye appeared normal. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Cataract with glaucoma with shallow anterior chamber: Phacomorphic glaucoma
  • Cataract with glaucoma with normal or deep anterior chamber: Phacolytic glaucoma

questions.text: Which of the following causative agents is responsible for the occurrence of delayed onset endophthalmitis after a cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
• Delayed onset endophthalmitis is a complication that occurs a week to a month after surgery.
  • The most common cause is fungi.
  • Propionibacterium acne is the second most common cause of delayed endophthalmitis.

questions.text: An 8 year old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of flu like symptoms, malaise and general weakness. He has a history of repeated and recurrent infections since the first year of life and the symptoms persist for a certain amount of time. Further examinations reveal enlargement of the liver and spleen with lymph node inflammation. On physical examination, there was a superficial rash resembling eczema. Laboratory results showed the neutrophils count is impaired. What might be the most likely cause of the child’s illness?
questions.solution:
• Patients having chronic granulomatous disease with defective functioning of phagocytic neutrophils and monocytes due to an inability to produce hydrogen peroxide.
  • The phagocytic cells have a decreased oxida- tive burst.
  • The MCC of chronic granulomatous disease is defective NADPH oxidase, an enzyme which converts Oxygen to superoxide stimulating oxygen burst.
  • This deficiency results in recurrent infections
  • chronic granulomatous diseases usually affect boys and cause death before the age of 10.
  • A defect in the enzyme adenosine deaminase is seen in severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID), autosomal recessive type
  • Whereas a defect in the IL-2 receptor is seen in the X-linked recessive form of SCID.
  • developmental failure of pharyngeal pouches 3 and 4 is characteristic of DiGeorge’s syndrome.

questions.text: On examination of a 2 year old child with leukocoria, a large unilateral retinoblastoma filling half the globe is found. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
— Indications for different treatment modalities of retinoblastoma are:

- Enucleation

• Intraocular retinoblastoma involving more than 50%of the globe

• Intraocular retinoblastoma extending to anterior segment

• Retinoblastoma with orbital extension (after chemoreduction)

- Focal therapy: Photocoagulation, Cryotherapy, Brachytherapy

• Small intraoculartumours

• Larger tumours may be treated with focal therapy after chemoreduction (to avoid enucleation)

- Chemotherapy

• Palliative therapy for retinoblastoma with metastasis

• Bilateral advanced retinoblastoma (to avoid bilateral enucleation)

• Chemoreduction

- Radiotherapy

• Advanced cases with intracranial extension

• Orbital radiotherapy for cases with extension to orbital wall

questions.text: A 67 year old female is brought to the emergency room by her grandson as she had developed bruising covering many areas of her body. The grandmother lives by herself and is not so attentive about her food and diet. On physical examination, small blood clots around hair follicles are visible, some of these follicles having a“corkscrew” appearance. Also there is gingival swelling,tenderness and bleeding. The above mentioned condition could be as a result of which deficiency of which vitamin ?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a water-soluble vitamin with multiple functions, such as the synthesis of collagen, osteoid, certain neurotrans- mitters, and carnitine.
  • In the synthesis of collagen, vitamin C functions as a cofactor for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine and for the formation of the triple helix of tropocollagen.
  • Patients with decreased vitamin C (scurvy) have abnormal synthesis of connective tissue due to abnormal synthesis of collagen along with abnormal synthesis of osteoid, Causing impaired wound healing.
  • Because the synthesis of collagen is abnormal, the blood vessels are fragile, leading to bleeding gums, subperiosteal hemorrhage, and petechial perifollicular skin hemorrhages

questions.text: A man presented to the OPD, and with complaints of constant ringing in his ears. He appeared to have skin depigmentation. On further examination, bilateral uveitis was found. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis that encompasses the stated features?
questions.solution:
- VKH syndrome is a multisystem, idiopathic disorder.

- It includes ocular, neurological and cutaneous manifestations.

- More common in Japanese population who are positive for HLA-DR4 and DW15. - Clinical features include:

A) Cutaneous lesions: alopecia, poliosis and vitiligo

B) Neurological lesions: meningism, and encephalopathy

C) Auditory features: tinnitus, vertigo and deafness

D) Ocular features include:

— Anterior uveitis: bilateral chronic granulomatous characterised by iris nodules, posterior synechiae.

— Posterior uveitis lesions include multifocal choroiditis leading to exudative retinal detachment, choroidal depigmentation (sunset glow fundus), Dalen-Fuch’s nodules and peripheral yellow-white choroidal granuloma.

questions.text: Toll like receptors recognize bacterial products & stimulate immune response by:

choices.text: Transcriptions of nuclear factor mediated by NFKb which recruits cytokines

questions.solution:
Mechanism of action of Toll like receptors: Activation of transcription factors like-

  • NF-kB: stimulates expression of adhesion molecules & causes activation of leukocytes
  • Interferon regulatory factors (IRFs): stimulates production of antiviral type I interferons

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of watering from his left eye since a year. A patent drainage system was revealed on syringing examination. The rest of his ocular examination was normal. A provisional diagnosis of a lacrimal pump failure was made. The confirmation of this diagnosis would be done by which of the following methods?
questions.solution:
• Lacrimal pump failure means inability of the lid muscles to push the tears towards the.punctum for drainage.
  • It is also called functional obstruction and is confirmed by Dacryoscintigraphy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents because of trouble with her vision. Physical examination reveals a very tall, thin woman with long, thin fingers. Examining her eyes reveals the lens of her left eye to be in the anterior chamber. Her blood levels of methionine and cystathionine are within normal levels. These signs and symptoms are caused by?
questions.solution: The clinical scenario describes a patient of Marfan syndrome which is an autosomal dominant disorder that results from defective synthesis of fibrillin

questions.text: Which one of the following is the accurate definition of a ‘cross-cylinder’?

choices.text: One spherical and one cylindrical lens

questions.solution:
• Cross cylinder is an instrument used to refine the power and axis of a cylinder during subjective refraction.
  • It consists of one plus and one minus cylinder of the same power but in the opposite axis.
  • The combination of a cylinder and a sphere of opposite and double power produces the same effect.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man, Gagan presents with increasing abdominal pain and jaundice. He gives a history of intake of groundnuts which did not taste appropriate. Physical examination reveals a large mass involving the right side of his liver, and a biopsy specimen from this mass confirms the diagnosis of liver cancer (hepatocellular carcinoma). Which of the following substances is associated with the pathogenesis of this tumor?
questions.solution:
• Vinyl chloride is MC associated with angiosarcoma of the liver, not hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Azo dyes, such as butter yellow and scarlet red, have induced hepatocellular cancer in rats, but no human cases have been reported.
  • There has been an increase in bladder cancer in workers in the aniline dye and rubber industries
  • Aflatoxin B1, a natural product of the fungus Aspergillus flavus, is associated with the high incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatitis B virus is also highly associated with liver cancer

questions.text: Lamina cribrosa is mesh-like structure that surrounds and supports the optic nerve head with the retinal ganglion. It is absent in which one of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
• Morning glory syndrome (MGS) is a congenital defect of the optic nerve.
  • Caused by outward herniation of the optic disc and peripapillary tissues due to abnormal closure of the embryonic fissure.
  • Characterized by a ‘flower’-like enlarged funnel-shaped cavity of the optic disc.

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby boy is evaluated because of repeated episodes of pneumococcal pneumonia. Serum studies demonstrate very low levels of IgM, IgG, and IgA. This condition of the patient is thought to be related to a deficiency of which of the following proteins?

choices.text: Gamma chain of the IL-2 receptor

questions.solution:
This patient has X linked agammaglobulinemia AKA Brouton's agammaglobulinemia, which occurs due to a deficiency in tyrosine kinase leading to B cell maturation arrest at the pre B cell level

Selective IgA defiency has been linked to defective class III MHC genes Severe combine immunodeficiency is apparantly a heterogenous disease and its different subgroups have been linked to abnormalities of adenosine deaminase, the gamma chain of the IL-2 receptor and of purine nucleotide phosphorylase

questions.text: Rahul Kumar Singh migrates from UP to Bihar to work under the NREGA scheme as a daily wage labourer. The district has high malaria endemicity. So, his physician gives him primaquine chemoprophylaxis for Plasmodium vivax malaria. Several days after beginning such a regimen,he develops anemia, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria. Special studies will likely reveal an abnormality in which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Drugs that cause oxidative stress (e.g., primaquine, sulfa-containing drugs) result in intravascular hemolytic anemia in individuals (most often male) with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • Duffy antigen is a minor red blood cell antigen, the absence of which provides resistance to malarial infection. Intrinsic factor may be absent in pernicious anemia.
  • PIG-A deficiency results in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

questions.text: During a summer camp, multiple children had to be hospitalized with symptoms resembling the ingestion of botulinum toxins. The effects of this toxin includes which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Spores of botulinum grow in the gut.
  • They produce toxins leading to descending paralysis.
  • It is prejunctional with a reduction in ACh release.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Bulbar Palsy
    • Diaphragmatic Palsy
  • All CN involvement, except I and II, leads to:
    • Dilated/ Fixed pupil
    • Dysphasia
    • Dysarthria

questions.text: A 6 year old child presents with pallor that required two blood transfusions previously. He has now developed fever and petechial haemorrhages. His hemoglobin is 9 g/dL, platelet count is 20,000/mm3 and TLC is 60,000/ mm3. Flow cytometry reveals the cells to be CD10+ve, MPO+ve,CD19+ve,CD33–ve,CD117+ve,and CD3 – ve. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Mixed lineage acute leukemia is alternatively also known as bilineal acute leukemia. As is suggested by the name, there are 2 populations of cells which are morphologically and immunophenotypically distinct from each other. Analyzing the markers on the cells,
  • Blymphoid markers: CD 10, CD19 and CD79
  • Tlineage markers: CD2. CD3 and CD7
  • Myeloid markers, CD13, CD33, CD117 and myeloperoxidase (MPO).
  • Non lineage specific markers which are expressed in hematopoietic progenitor cells: CD34, HLA-DR and TOT
  • Comparing this with the information provided in the question, it is easy to decipher that the cells mentioned are CD10+ve, MPO +ve, CD19+ve, CD33-ve, CD117 +ve and CD3-ve which is showing both lymphoid (CD10, CD19B lymphoid lineage) and myeloid (CD117 and MPO, myeloid lineage) markers. So, the answer is Mixed phenotypic leukemia

questions.text: Wblood sample is taken from a patient as a baseline measurement after which Drug A is administered intravenously. Additional blood samples are taken periodically and the drug concentration is measured in each blood sample. This sampling is repeated, with oral drug administration this time. A logarithm of drug concentration v/s time is plotted from data from both administration routes. Comparable elimination 'curves' indicative of first-order kinetic elimination is indicated. What do the slopes of the resulting concentration vs. time curves tell us best about the pharmacokinetics of Drug A?
questions.solution:
• Regardless of which administration route has been used, if we plot the log of serum concentration of a drug vs. time (and assuming first-order kinetics, which applies to the elimination of most drugs when blood levels are therapeutic after initial redistribution), we get a straight line.
  • It is described by the equation

  • The slope of 'k' is the elimination rate constant.
  • Another measure of the rate at which a drug is eliminated is the half-life (t1/2).
  • t1/2 = 0.693/k, and is defined as the time it takes for the concentration of a drug in the blood to fall to precisely one half of what it is now (or at any specified time).

questions.text: A 28 year old woman presents to OPD complaining of nosebleeds. She also has easy bruising and excessively heavy bleeding during her periods. There is no history of drug intake. Physical examination shows scattered petechiae with normal sized spleen. Laboratory examination shows platelet count of 37000/microliter and a bleeding time of 16 minutes. The bone marrow sometimes shows an increased number of megakaryocytes. Antinuclear antibodies are negative. Autoantibodies that are directed against which of the following antigens would likely be found in this patient’s serum?
questions.solution:
• The history of nosebleeds and menorrhagia, the petechiae, thrombocytopenia and increased bleeding time all suggest a platelet disorder.
  • The decreased platelet count suggests a thrombocytopenic disorder rather than a platelet function disorder.
  • The absence of antinuclear antibody rules out SLE (a significant cause of thrombocytopenia).
  • The negative drug history rules out drug-associated thrombocytopenia.
  • So, a probable diagnosis of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura can be made.
  • ITP is an acquired thrombocytopenia caused by formation of autoantibodies directed against the platelet mem- brane proteins glycoprotein IIb/IIIa, followed by splenic destruction of opsonized platelets.
  • The disease typically occurs in women from 20-40 years of age.
  • Antibodies to erythrocyte membrane proteins are seen in autoimmune hemolytic anemia whereas antibodies to intrinsic factor are seen in pernicious anemia

questions.text: A drug user self-administers cocaine. This causes him to experience significant changes in cardiovascular changes and CNS- stimulating effects for which the drug is used. Which one of the following listed answers is the most likely mechanism by which cocaine causes its main peripheral and CNS effects?

choices.text: Activation of α2-adrenergic receptors leading to increased NE release
Blockage of NE reuptake via the amine pump
Direct activation postsynaptic α- and β-adrenergic receptors, leading to sympathomimetic (adrenomimetic) responses
Inhibition of MAO, leading to increased intraneuronal NE levels

questions.solution:
• Cocaine and tricyclic antidepressants such as imipramine are examples of drugs that inhibit NE reuptake by the “amine pump."
  • This is the main process by which released NE re-enters the neuron.
  • Thus, its receptor-mediated effects are terminated physiologically.
  • In the presence of cocaine or a TCA, released NE lingers and accumulates in the synapse (neuroeffector junction), and so pertinent adrenergic responses appear heightened or more intense, and prolonged.
  • Provided an adrenergic nerve is present (as it is in the diagram), the effects of cocaine or a tricyclic antidepressant are not affected by or dependent on whether the effector is smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, or an exocrine gland of any sort.
  • There is no such direct functional link between the amine pump and processes such as NE release (exocytotically or otherwise) or activation of presynaptic (α2-) adrenergic receptors.

questions.text: A 30 year old male with exertional calf pain and painful foot ulcers demonstrates hypersensitivity to intradermally injected tobacco extract. Which of the following pathologic processes is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Onion-like concentric thickening of arteriolar walls
Transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with fibrinoid necrosis
Segmental vasculitis extending into contiguous veins and nerves

questions.solution:
• He is most likely suffering from Buerger’s disease (Young male with hypersensitivity to tobacco). Microscopically the condition shows.
  • Segmental thrombosing vasculitis often extending into contiguous veins and nerves (a feature rarely seen in other types of vasculitis), encasing them in fibrous tissue.
  • Lipid-filled intimal plaques that bulge into the arterial lumen are seen in atherosclerosis.
  • Onion-like concentric thickening of arteriolar walls as a result of laminated smooth muscle cells and redu- plicated basement membranes is seen in hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis (seen in malignant hypertension)
  • Transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with fibrinoid necrosis is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

questions.text: A 40 year old woman with diagnosed myasthenia gravis presents with profound skeletal muscle weakness. It is unsure whether she is experiencing a cholinergic crisis or a myasthenic crisis, so an appropriate dose of parenteral edrophonium is administered. Assuming that the patient was actually experiencing a cholinergic crisis, which of the following is the most likely response to the drug?

choices.text: Hypertensive crisis from peripheral vascular constriction

questions.solution:
• Edrophonium is a fast and short-acting parenteral acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.
  • The patient is dealing with a cholinergic crisis, meaning she has received excessive doses of the oral cholinesterase inhibitor (e.g., pyridostigmine, neostigmine, several others) used to manage her myasthenia gravis.
  • Due to this dosage excess, and the excess ACh accumulating at the skeletal neuromuscular junctions (owing to reduced metabolic inactivation of the neurotransmitter), the patient's skeletal muscles are fatigued from overstimulation of nicotinic receptors by the ACh.
  • This skeletal muscle hypofunction involves muscles in the extremities, diaphragm and intercostals that need to function normally for adequate and appropriate ventilation.
  • When a cholinesterase inhibitor is given to such patients, who are already experiencing excessive cholinergic effects, there is overactivation of the diaphragm and intercostals, which may be sufficient to cause ventilatory distress or total ventilatory failure.
  • This is the main reason why the “edrophonium test” is dangerous if the underlying problem is actually a cholinergic crisis.
  • Edrophonium is preferred to other ACh esterase inhibitors because it has a very short duration of action (highly desirable should adverse effects occur).

questions.text: Identify the drug that is suitable for topical administration (e.g., to mucous membranes), but cannot be given parenterally because of its physicochemical properties, which render it very poorly soluble.
questions.solution:
• Almost all local anesthetics contain a lipophilic functional group, and most have a hydrophilic group (e.g., amine).
  • Benzocaine does not possess the terminal hydrophilic group; hence, it is only slightly soluble in water.
  • It is also extremely slowly absorbed. It is, hence, only useful as a topical anesthetic (e.g., on mucous membranes).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs would be most suitable in the outpatient prophylaxis of a patient with recurring periodic episodes of PSVT?
questions.solution:
• Verapamil is a nondihydropyridine CCB that depresses both the SA node and the AV node.
  • Hence, would be effective for prophylaxis of paroxysmal atrial or supraventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 63 year old woman, normotensive, is transferred to the surgical ICU after cardiac surgery. She has diffuse rales bilaterally, pulse = 110/min, a raised venous pressure, and BP = 165/95 mm Hg. An incorrect syringe that contains the wrong drug is given to this patient to control her heart rate and blood pressure. The patient’s pulse rate increases to 150/min and her blood pressure is now 185/107 mmHg. Which of the following drugs was likely to be given?
questions.solution:
• Intravenous infusion of dobutamine, a β1 agonist, was the most likely cause of the increased heart rate.
  • Blood pressure rises in Dobutamine administration secondary to a positive inotropic effect of the drug, instead of by any direct peripheral vasoconstrictor activity.

questions.text: A patient, who has been taking an oral diuretic for the past 6 months, presents with a raised fasting and postprandial blood glucose levels. His HbA1c levels are also elevated compared to his previous normal baseline values of 6 months ago. His glycemic problems are suspected to be diuretic-induced. Which one of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Thiazides and thiazide-like diuretics (e.g., chlorthiazide) may raise blood glucose levels, impair glucose tolerance, and cause frank hyperglycemia.
  • Loop diuretics are suspected to have the same effects.
  • The mechanisms to explain the effects are: decreased release of insulin from the pancreas; increased glycogenolysis and reduced glucogenesis; there is a reduction in the conversion of proinsulin to insulin; and a decreased responsiveness of adipocyte and skeletal myocyte insulin receptor response to the hormone.

questions.text: A 24 year old patient with asthma is being treated with a drug called montelukast. Which one of the following is the main mechanism by which this drug functions?

choices.text: Blocking of the proinflammatory effects of some arachidonic acid metabolites
Enhanced release of epinephrine from the adrenal medulla
Inhibition of cAMP breakdown, via phosphodiesterase inhibition

questions.solution:
• Montelukast, and zafirlukast, block receptors for leukotrienes (LTs).
  • LTs are proinflammatory and bronchoconstrictor mediators formed as part of normal arachidonic acid metabolism via the 5’- lipoxygenase pathway.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with a rich history of frequent and moderately severe migraine headaches. When 'sumatriptan', a commonly used drug for abortive therapy is given, which one of the following 'local control substances' does it mainly act on?
questions.solution:
• Acute migraine therapy: involves giving a drug that mimics the effects of endogenous serotonin, this causes reversal of the cerebrovasodilation that contributes significantly to migraine signs.
  • Sumatriptan: 5-HT1B/2D receptor agonists, is a good example of this.

questions.text: Fat-soluble vitamins, compared with their water-soluble counterparts, usually have a greater potential toxicity to the user when taken in excess. Which one of the following most accurately states the focal reason for this finding?

choices.text: Involved in more essential metabolic pathways

questions.solution:
• Fat-soluble vitamins, particularly A and D, can be stored in massive amounts and, therefore, have a potential for serious toxicities.
  • Water-soluble vitamins are relatively easily excreted by the kidneys and accumulation to toxic levels is much less common.
  • Conversely, inadequate dietary intake will lead to manifestations of deficiency relatively faster.

questions.text: A few patients, who are taking high doses of a bisphosphonate for Paget’s disease of the bone develop an endocrine-metabolic disorder. Which one of the following is the most likely disorder?
questions.solution:
• Bisphosphonates mainly affect bone Ca2+ metabolism, and the parathyroid gland is the main regulator of serum Ca2+ levels.
  • When a bisphosphonate is administered to a patient with Paget’s disease of the bone, after about a week the dramatic inhibition of bone resorption dramatically lowers serum Ca2+ levels (because an important portion of serum Ca2+ arises from bone that is being resorbed).
  • When serum Ca2+ falls considerably, parathyroid hyperfunction can develop.
  • The easiest way to prevent this would be to administer dietary calcium supplements along with the bisphosphonate.

questions.text: A 60 year old security guard presents to the his physician because he is having malaise, fever and weakness. On taking history, a positive history of multiple episodes of passage of altered colored urine is present. However, this is not associated with urinary frequency, dysuria, or nocturia. Physical examination is insignificant but his urine analysis reveals 4 + hematuria; 1 + proteinuria and absence of glucose or ketones by the dipstick method. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step for the management of this patient?

choices.text: Abdominal CT scan for renal mass
Collection of a 24 hour urine specimen for protein

questions.solution:
• Painless hematuria in an old patient is highly suggestive of a renal malignancy. Moreover, additional presence of consti- tutional symptoms, such as fever and weakness, increase the suspicion of a renal cell carcinoma.
  • Urinary tract calculi usually cause severe, colicky pain when they are passed.
  • Nephrotic syndrome, which manifests with proteinuria, typically is not associated with hematuria,
  • A renal biopsy has a less diagnostic yield in a condition without an acute onset renal disease, and it is not very effective for diagnosing neoplasms

questions.text: A patient presented to the ER with symptoms of a fine tremor in their hands and fingers, heat sensitivity and moist skin. He complained of a faster, irregular heartbeat and appeared to have and enlarged goiter on examination, with bulged, swollen eyes. A provisional diagnosis was made. This diagnosis follows a possible pathogenesis of which of the following options?
questions.solution:
TYPE 2 HR takes place by

A Opsonisation & Phagocytosis

B Inflammation

C Antibody induced Tissue dysfunction

MECHANISMS

A. OPSONISATION & PHASOCYTOSIS

1. Direct Antibody mediated Opsonisation

IG → Neutrophils, Macrophages [opsonin]

2. ADCC [ Antibody Dependent Cell mediated cytotoxicity]

3. Via Complement activation

EXAMPLES

· RH INCOMPATIBILITY

· BLOOD TRANSFUSION REACTION

· AUTO IMMUNE HEMOLYTIC ANEMIA

· AUTO IMMUNE THROMBOCYTOPENIA

· AUTO IMMUNE LEUCOPENIA

B. COMPLEMENT ACTIVATION & INDUCTION OF INFLAMATION

Ag + Formation

© System Activation ↓ C3a, C5a → ↑ Neutrophils, Macrophages → Chemicals → Tissue Damage

EXAMPLES

· ACUTE RHEUMATIC FEVER

· GOODPASTURE SYNDROME

· ANCA - mediated VASCULITIES

· Pemphigus Vulgaris - Ab formed against cadherin molecule [skin DS]

C. Ab INDUCED TISSUE DYSFUNCTION / CELLULAR DISFUNCTION

Binds Tissue ↑ Stimulation of receptor
To ↓ Stimulation of receptor

EXAMPLES

· MYASTHENIA GRAVIS ↓

· GRAVES DISEASE [ ↑↑ stimulation of TSH receptors]

· PERNICIOUS ANEMIA

· INSULIN RESISTANT DIABETES

questions.text: The depicted image is from a liver biopsy of a 34-year-old woman with a long history of alcoholism. Which of the following explains the changes shown here most appropriately?

choices.text: Apoptosis with a replacement of damaged cells by lipid-laden macrophages
Bilirubin accumulation with mobilization of fat by bile salts

questions.solution:
- The figure shows fatty change of the liver, which is characterized by the accumulation of intracellular parenchymal triglycerides.

- It is seen most frequently in the liver, heart, and kidney and is commonly secondary to alcoholism.

- Fatty change results from an imbalance in between the uptake, the utilization, and the mobilization of the fat from hepatic cells. Alcoholic fatty liver might be reversible with complete abstinence from alcohol

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is diagnosed with ALL. Which of the following cytogenetic changes would show a good prognosis?
questions.solution:
- t(12;21) and high hyperdiploidy are associated with positive outcomes in ALL.

- t(9;22), t(1;19), 11q23 rearrangements, and hypodiploidy are all associated with poor prognosis in these leukemias.

- The 9;22 translocation seen in ALL is cytogenetically identical but molecularly distinct from the one typically seen in CML.

questions.text: Which of one the following conditions best describes the mechanism through which Fas(CD95) initiates apoptosis?
questions.solution:
- Apoptosis has two basic phases: an initiation phase, during which caspases are activated, and an execution phase, during which cell death occurs.

  • The initiation phase has two distinct pathways: the extrinsic (receptor mediated) pathway and the intrinsic (or mitochondrial) pathway.
  • The extrinsic pathway is mostly mediated by cell surface death receptors, two example of death receptors are:

— type I TNF receptor (TNFR1)

— Fas (CD95)

- Fas ligand (FasL), which is produced by immune cells, stimulates apoptosis by binding to Fas, which activates the cytoplasmic Fas-associated death domain protein (FADD), which in turn activates the caspase cascade via the activation of caspase 8.

  • In contrast to the extrinsic pathway, the intrinsic pathway does not involve death receptors and instead results from increased permeability of mitochondria.

questions.text: The most important characteristic of a water-insoluble substance that governs its diffusibility through a cell membrane is its:
questions.solution:
• Materials that are isoluble in water can only cross the membrane through the phospholipid bilayer.
  • Thus, the factor which is most important in determining how well a substance can diffuse across the lipid bilayer is the substance’s lipid solubility.
  • If two materials have the same lipid solubility, then the permeability of the smaller particle will be greater.

questions.text: A 28 year old woman cones to the OPD with complains of slightly increased vaginal discharge since 1 month. A cervical Pap smear is shown below. Superficial epithelial cells are identified with the arrows. When compared to the cells from the deeper intermediate layer (top), the nuclei of these superficial cells may exhibit which of the following cytologic features?
questions.solution:
- The given image shows a diagnosis of: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, pyknosis.

- Coagulative necrosis refers to light microscopic alterations in dying cells.

- When stained with the usual combination of hematoxylin and eosin, the cytoplasm of a necrotic cell is eosinophilic.

- The nucleus displays an initial clumping of chromatin followed by its redistribution along the nuclear membrane.

- In pyknosis, the nucleus becomes smaller and stains deeply basophilic as chromatin clumping continues.

- Karyorrhexis (choice B) and karyolysis (choice A) represent further steps in the fragmentation and dissolution of the nucleus.

- These steps are not evident in the necrotic cells shown in this Pap smear

questions.text: Which of the following is the best index of preload?
questions.solution:
• Preload: the sarcomere length at the end of diastole.
  • Left ventricular end-diatolic volume: parameter most directly related to sarcomere length during this time period.

questions.text: A first-degree heart-block is diagnosed through which of the following findings?

choices.text: The PR interval of the ECG is increased
The P wave of the ECG is never followed by a QRS complex
The P wave of the ECG is sometimes followed by a QRS complex
The T wave of the ECG is inverted

questions.solution:
• PR interval: time taken for the cardiac action potential to propagate from the SA node to the ventricular muscle. A delay in this interval is called a first- degree heart block.
  • A second-degree heart block occurs when the action potential does not always propagate through the SA node. This produces an uneven heart beat.
  • A third-degree block occurs when the action potential never reaches the ventricle. Here, pacemakers within the ventricle produce ventricular contraction but the rate is very slow.
  • Inversion of the T wave and elevation of the ECG are indicators of membrane potential defects within the ventricular muscle.

questions.text: Cross-sectional studies are usually based on primary data, collected by the interviewer himself. It is a constituent of which one of the following?
questions.solution:
- Analytical studies are done to examine the relationships between health status and other variables.

- Analytical studies include:

— ecological studies

— cross-sectional studies

— case-control studies

— cohort studies

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dependant factor for the percentage of the total cardiac output distributed to any single organ?

choices.text: Ratio of an organ’s vascular resistance to total peripheral resistance

questions.solution:
• The relative resistance of each parallel arterial pathway (that supplies the major organs) determines the distribution of blood flow through a network of vessels, which is also parallel.
  • Ratio of that relative resistance to the total resistance: determines the percentage of flow going through each of the parallel networks.

questions.text: The theory of ‘Disease causation’ is best described by which one of the following:

choices.text: heory of one-to-one relationship between causal agent and disease

questions.solution:
- Germ theory of disease. i.e. one-to-one relationship between causal agents (microbes) and disease held ground throughout the early part of the 20 century.

- It demolished the supernatural theory of disease.

- The modern concept of disease causation is '' Web of Causation" suggested by McMahon and Pugg.

- It largely dwells on the multi-factorial causation as well as the well-known 'epidemiological triad of disease' being the result of interplay of agent, host and environmental factors

questions.text: Regarding small intestinal motility, which one of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Contractile activity: initiated in response to bowel wall distention
Peristalsis: major contractile pattern during feeding
Migrating motor complexes: occur during the digestive period
Vagotomy: abolishes contractile activity during the digestive period

questions.solution:
• Segmentation: is the primary motility pattern of the digestive period in humans
  • It is irregular and uncoordinated contraction of the circular muscle layer.
  • It develops in response to intestinal wall distention and is determined by activation of preprogrammed neural circuits within the myenteric plexus.
  • The contractions, called electrical slow waves, reduce from approximately 11/minute in the duodenum to approximately 6 to 7/minute in the distal ileum.

questions.text: Supposing randomisation is done in a controlled clinical trial to determine a comparison between two treatment groups, the main purpose of this randomisation would be:

choices.text: The allocation of participants in each treatment group is independent of the clinician’s control
The sample can be referenced to a known population.
The treatments received by each subject can be predicted by the clinician.
The two groups will have the same prognostic factors.

questions.solution:
- Randomisation: is done to remove selection bias and confounding errors.

- i.e, Randomisation is done to ensure that the investigator has no control over the selection of the participants.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about medium-chain fatty acids is accurate?

choices.text: More water-soluble than long-chain fatty acids
Used for triglyceride resynthesis, within the enterocyte

questions.solution:
• Medium-chain triglycerides: hydrolyzed by lipases more rapidly than long-chain fatty acids; much more water-soluble than long-chain triglycerides.
  • MCTs: fatty acids of 6 to 12 carbon chain lengths, present in small amounts in the normal diet.
  • MCTs: not utilized for resynthesis of triglycerides and hence are not packaged into chylomicrons.
  • They are released directly into the portal blood.
  • MCTs can be used in patients with a wide variety of GI diseases resulting in malabsorption, as they are readily absorbed.

questions.text: A host in which the organism is alive, without further development, is which one of the following:
questions.solution:
- Obligate host: one where the organism is the only host to the parasite

- Intermediate host: aka Secondary host, where the parasite exists in a larval/ asexual state

- Definitive host: aka Primary host, where a parasite attains sexual maturity after passing through its sexual phase

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Amphixenoses, except:

choices.text: It is a disease, which is epidemic in bird populations.
It is maintained in both humans and lower vertebrates.
It is displayed by Trypanosoma cruzi.
It can be transmitted in both directions between its vectors.

questions.solution:
- Epornithic diseases are those which are epidemic in a bird population.

- It is similar to epidemics in human populations.

questions.text: A patient, with raised basal and maximal acid outputs, reduced serum calcium levels and microcytic anemia, would be found to have which area of the GIT inflamed?
questions.solution:
• Inflammation of the duodenum: can cause increased acid output, hypocalcemia, and microcytic anemia.
  • Excessive stimulation of the parietal cells (e.g., hypergastrinemia) or reduced inhibitory feedback (i.e., reduced effect of enterogastrone and the enterogastric reflex) may result in increased basal and maximal acid outputs may result from .

questions.text: Which of the following does herd immunity threshold NOT vary with?

choices.text: The vaccine efficacy for the disease
The number of vaccines available for the disease
The documented virulence of the disease

questions.solution:
- Herd immunity is the protection level of the community against the particular disease caused by immunisation or vaccination.

- The proportion of the population above which a disease doesn’t spread any longer is known as the ‘herd threshold immunity’. - ---- This threshold is dependant on the following factors:

- Virulence of the disease

- Efficacy of the vaccine Contact parameters for the population

questions.text: Precurrent disinfection includes which of the following examples:
questions.solution:
- Terminal disinfection is that which is done after the transfer, isolation cessation or death of a patient.

- Concurrent disinfection is the use of disinfection procedures after the discharge of infectious material from an infected person, pre or post-surgical.

- Precurrent or prophylactic disinfection is that which is done as a prophylactic tactic. It includes:

- Chlorination of water

- Pasteurisation of milk

- Hand washing techniques

questions.text: A student presented to the ER with a two-day history of severe vomiting and orthostatic hypotension. What kind of metabolic abnormalities be expected?

choices.text: Normal serum electrolytes and metabolic acidosis
Normal serum electrolytes and metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
?-? Analysis of serum electrolytes would reveal: hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

?-? These abnormalities arise from:

-- Gastric juice contains potassium and chloride in concentrations higher than the plasma. Loss of gastric juice through vomiting causes depletions of these electrolytes from the plasma.

-- Metabolic abnormalities are exacerbated by the patient's dehydration.

?-? The contraction of the vascular volume leads to orthostatic hypotension and the activation of renal mechanisms to conserve volume. ?-? Hence, water, sodium, and bicarbonate are reabsorbed at the expense of increased potassium and hydrogen excretion.

questions.text: The difference in time between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis is known as:
questions.solution:
- Lag time: time between the onset of disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

- Screening is done when there is a consideration time lag. The period between the first possible time of detection of disease and the usual time of diagnosis is known as the ‘lead time’.

questions.text: Identify the wrong pair among the following:

choices.text: Propagative transmission - Plague Bacilli in rat fleas
Cyclo developmental transmission - Microfilaria in mosquitoes
Transovarial transmission - Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks
Transstadial transmission - Schistosoma hematobium eggs in feces

questions.solution: - Transstadial transmission is when the infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next. Eg, borrelia burgdoferi in ticks.

questions.text: Hyperventilation in response to a stressful situation leads to which of the following physiological responses?

choices.text: Reduction in the blood flow to the brain
Decreased in the excitability of nerve and muscle cells
Decreased pH of the arterial blood
Increased resistance of the pulmonary blood vessels

questions.solution:
• Hyperventilation reduces the arterial PCO2 below normal, that is, to a value less than 40 mmHg.
  • Low arterial PCO2 in the blood perfusing the brain causes vasoconstriction of the cerebral vasculature, leading to a lowering of blood flow to the brain.
  • The low arterial CO2 will increase the pH of the arterial blood (i.e., produce a respiratory alkalosis) and decrease the activity of the central chemoreceptors.
  • Pulmonary vasculature, unlike the systemic vas- culature, is dilated by low PCO2 and high PO2 and constricted by high PCO2 and low PO2.
  • The respiratory alkalosis will cause Ca2+ to bind to plasma proteins, lowering the concentration of ionized Ca2+.
  • Low concentrations of ionized Ca2+ increase the excitability of nerve and muscle membranes, causing them to contract spontaneously or with minimal stimulation.
  • The increased contractile activity of skeletal muscle produced by low concentration of ionized Ca2+ is called tetany.

questions.text: When a substance appears in the renal artery but not in the renal vein, which of the following would be true in this case?

choices.text: Its clearance is equal to the glomerular filtration rate
Its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow
It must be reabsorbed by the kidney
It must be filtered by the kidney

questions.solution:
• If a substance disappears from the circulation during its passage through the kidney, it usually denotes that it has been completely secreted into the nephron.
  • In this case, its clearance will be equal to the RPF/ renal plasma flow.
  • If the substance is bound to the plasma proteins, it can be secreted without being filtered.
  • Even if it is entirely secreted by the kidney, the substance's urinary concentration may be less than its plasma concentration, provided the urinary flow rate is very high.

questions.text: All of the following are features of a rash from chicken pox, except:
questions.solution:
— Characteristics of a chicken pox rash include:

- Centripetal

- Pleomorphic

- Superficial

- Unilocular

- Symmetrical

- Dew-drops on rose-petal appearance

- Rapid evolution

- Spares palms and soles

- Affects flexor surfaces and Axilla

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding HCV screening, except:

choices.text: IV drug users are more susceptible to infection
Long term hemodialysis patients are not prone to infection

questions.solution:
- Indications for HCV screening include:

- Transfusion or transplant patients

- Injectable drug users

- Patients on long term hemodialysis

- Infants born to infected mothers

- HIV patients Healthcare workers

questions.text: The anti-inflammatory effect of cortisol treatment is thought to be as a result of:
questions.solution:
• The anti-inflammatory effects of exogenous cortisol are due to its ability to decrease capillary membrane permeability, stabilize lysosomal membranes and decrease the formation of bradykinin.
  • Glucocorticoids: inhibit enzyme phospholipase A2.
  • This reduces the release of arachidonic acid and the variety of substances produced from it, such as:

-- leukotrienes

-- prostaglandins

-- prostacyclin

-- thromboxanes

  • Cortisol's fever-reducing action is due to the hormone’s ability to decrease the release of pyrogen (interleukin 1) from granulocytes.
  • How ever, only in massive doses will Cortisol achieve these effects.
  • Endogenous cortisol does not exert significant anti-inflammatory action.

questions.text: An incubation period of 28 days is seen with:
questions.solution:
- P. Falciparum - 12 days

- P. Vivax -14 days

- P. Ovale - 17 days

- P. Malariae - 28 days

questions.text: Repeated stimulation of a skeletal muscle fiber will result in an increase in contractile strength because repetitive stimulation causes an increase in which one of the following?

choices.text: Concentration of calcium in the myoplasm

questions.solution:
• Every time a skeletal muscle fiber is stimulated by an alpha motoneuron, there is enough Ca2+ release from its sarcoplasmic reticulum needed to fully activate all the troponin within the muscle.
  • So, every cross bridge contributes to tension generation.
  • However, the transmission of force from the cross bridges to the tendon or bone does not occur until the series elastic component (SEC) of the muscle is stretched.
  • Repetitive firing increases the amount of SEC stretch by maintaining cross-bridge cycling for a longer period of time.
  • This occurs because each time the muscle is activated, the Ca2+ released from the SR replaces the Ca2+ that has been resequestered since the last stimulus.

questions.text: Which of the following schedules are correct regarding pre-exposure prophylaxis of Rabies?
questions.solution: - Pre-exposure prophylaxis of rabies is given on days 0, 7, 21 or 28.

questions.text: The drug regimen recommended for a needle stick injury from a HIV positive patient is which one of the following?`
questions.solution:
- The recommended post-exposure prophylaxis drug regimen is:

- Lamivudine 300mg (3TC)

- Tenofovir 300mg (TDF)

- Dolutegravir 50mg (DTG)

- These drugs are given in combination with each other, once daily, for a duration of 4 weeks.

questions.text: The criteria for an ideal candidate for IUD insertion includes which one of the following:

choices.text: The criteria for an ideal candidate for IUD insertion includes which one of the following:

questions.solution:
- Characteristics of an ideal IUD candidate include:

- No history of PID

- Normal menstrual periods

- Willing to check IUD tail

- With access to follow up

- Monogamy Has Atleast one child

questions.text: A provision by the State, of medical service and education, but operated and regulated by professional groups, NOT the government would be the definition of which one of the following terms?
questions.solution:
- Social medicine: An organised investigation of environmental, social, genetic factors affecting disease patterns and disabilities.

- Social pathology: study of social factors that incite social disorganisation, and not just affect human disease. This includes abuse, crime, poverty, vandalism, etc

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with complaints that she has heard voices for the past six months. Besides the auditory hallucinations, she says that the radio is giving her special messages. When asked by the meaning of “People in glass houses should not throw stones,” she replies, “Because the windows would break.” Which one of the following mental status findings does this patient appear to display?
questions.solution:
• Patients with concrete thinking have lost their ability to form and understand abstract concepts, such as metaphors, and focus instead on facts.
  • Concrete thinking is normal in children and is seen in schizophrenia and cognitive disorders (mental retardation, dementia).

questions.text: A 3-year-old child carries around a tattered, old blanket everywhere he goes. Whenever he is upset, he calms himself by hugging and stroking his blanket. He also requires it to settle down before he goes to sleep. Which one of the following does his blanket represent for this child?
questions.solution:
• Winnicott coined the term transitional object, usually a toy or a blanket, that represents a comforting substitute for the primary caregiver.
  • Thanks to a transitional object, the child can tolerate separation from the mother without excessive anxiety.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is brought to the ER by his friends after he “took a few pills” at a party and developed symptoms, including his neck twisting to one side, eyes rolling upward, and tongue hanging out of his mouth. He responded immediately to 50 mg of diphenhydramine i/m with the resolution of all physical symptoms. Which one of the following substances is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Acute dystonic reaction: adverse effect of neuroleptic medications secondary to blockage of dopamine receptors in the nigrostriatal system
  • Dystonic reactions: sustained spasmodic contractions of the extraocular muscles and muscles of the neck, trunk, tongue, face, and extraocular muscles.
  • Painful and frightening.
  • Usually occur within hours to 3 days after the beginning of the neuroleptic treatment.
  • Occasionally seen in young people who have ingested a neuroleptic medication, mistaking it for a drug of abuse.
  • Administration of anticholinergic drugs provides rapid treatment of acute dystonia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman slips on the ice and hits her head on the pavement. During the following three weeks, she develops a persistent headache, is increasingly distractible and forgetful, and becomes fearful and disoriented at night. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these changes?
questions.solution:
• Chronic subdural hematoma causes a reversible form of dementia.
  • It frequently follows head trauma (60% of the cases), with tearing of the bridging veins in the subdural space.
  • Ruptured aneurysms, rapid deceleration injuries, and arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) of the pial surface account for the non-traumatic cases.
  • The most common symptoms of chronic subdural hematomas are headache, confusion, inattention, apathy, memory loss, drowsiness, and coma.
  • Lateralization signs, such as hemiparesis, hemianopsia, and cranial nerve abnormalities, are less prominent features.

questions.text: A 30 week old previously healthy male infant presents with fevers, abdominal distention, feeding intolerance, and bloody stools at 3 weeks of age. The patient undergoes x-ray and ultrasound examination for possible necrotizing enterocolitis. Which of the following findings on imaging is an indication for surgical management?
questions.solution:
• The patient’s presentation and radiologic findings are classic for necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC).
  • All of the listed radiologic findings are seen in neonates with NEC, but the main indication for surgical management is intestinal perforation, proved by pneumoperitoneum.
  • NEC - most common gastrointestinal emergency in neonatal period.
  • Prematurity - most important risk factor
  • 80% cases: occur within the first month of neonatal life.
  • Initial management: bowel rest with nasogastric tube decompression, fluid resuscitation, broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Medical management: successful in 50% cases
  • Surgery: done in patients with abdominal wall cellulitis, falling WBC count or platelet count, palpable abdominal mass, persistent fixed loop on abdominal films, intestinal perforation

questions.text: A neonate is examined in nursery and found to have no anal orifice; only a small perineal fistulous opening is visualized. Which of the following is associated with this abnormality?
questions.solution:
• The neonate has a low imperforate anus.
  • Treatment: perineal operation
  • Imperforate anus: type of anorectal malformation that affects both males and females with the same frequency, occurring in 1 in 5000 live births.
  • Occurs due to failure of descent of the urorectal septum.
  • Anorectal malformations: possibly associated with other anomalies including heart disease, esophageal atresia (EA), abnormalities of the lumbosacral spine, double urinary collecting systems, hydronephrosis, and communication between the rectum and the urinary tract, vagina, or perineum.
  • Patients may present with a number of anomalies collectively known as the VACTERL syndrome:
  • Vertebral anomalies
  • Anal atresia
  • Cardiac defect (eg, ventricular septal defect [VSD])
  • TracheoEsophageal fistula
  • Renal anomalies
  • Limb defects (eg, radial dysplasia).

questions.text: A 60 year old man is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma to the right internal jugular lymph node chain. Workup including CT and MRI head and neck are negative for a primary malignancy. Which of the following is the next appropriate step in the workup of this patient?

choices.text: Neck ultrasound of the thyroid and bilateral cervical lymph nodes
Selective sampling of cervical lymph nodes

questions.solution:
• The patient has cervical lymph nodes metastases with an unknown primary.
  • The most likely site of the primary is in the upper aerodigestive tract.
  • Therefore, the next step after negative imaging is to perform pan or triple endoscopy which includes laryngoscopy, nasopharyngoscopy, and esophagoscopy (upper endoscopy).
  • Directed tissue biopsies should be performed during examination under anesthesia and pan-endoscopy.
  • However, selective cervical lymph node sampling is not indicated.
  • Furthermore, modified radical neck dissection should not be performed without first performing pan-endoscopy to attempt to identify the primary malignancy.
  • Modified barium swallow has no role in identifying malignancy and is primarily used in evaluating swallowing.
  • Neck ultrasound is of little use given the negative CT and MRI scans

questions.text: A 15 year old boy is brought to the ER due to nasal fullness and bleeding. Inspection reveals enlarged cervical lymph nodes as well. What viral infection is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • A strong association exists with nasopharyngeal carcinoma and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections.
  • Diagnosis of nasopharyngeal cancer, tending to arise in relatively young people, should be made by biopsy of the primary tumor.
  • Human papilloma virus (HPV) is associated with oropharyngeal cancers via direct sexual contact.
  • Human herpes virus 8 (HHV-8) is associated with Kaposi sarcoma.
  • Hepatitis B and C viruses are associated with hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 46 year old woman presents to the OPD with a left-sided weakness. CT-head shows a well-circumscribed mass, against the skull in the right hemisphere. Workup of the mass reveals a meningioma. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in the treatment of this patient?

choices.text: Preoperative radiation therapy, followed by surgical excision

questions.solution:
• The primary treatment of meningiomas is surgical excision with adjuvant radiation therapy if complete excision is not possible.
  • Cerebral embolization has only been used preoperatively to reduce blood loss and as a palliative option for patients who are poor surgical candidates. However, it is not a definitive therapeutic modality

questions.text: A depressed student severed her own wrist’s radial nerve, in a botched suicide attempt. Which one of the following would be her anticipated disability?

choices.text: Wasting of intrinsic muscles of hand
Thenar pad and thumb web sensory loss

questions.solution:
• A radial nerve injury at the wrist would cause sensory abnormalities, primarily.
  • The areas that become insensate are:
  • Dorsum of hand from radial aspect of the 4th digit over the thumb
  • Thenar pad
  • Thumb web
  • If the radial injury is more proximal, the extension of the wrist and digits and forearm supination would also be impaired.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding nasopharyngeal cancer is true?

choices.text: Unusually high incidence among the Chinese
Wide surgical excision is the TOC
Occurs primarily after the sixth decade of life
Undergoes early metastasis to the lungs

questions.solution:
• There is an unusually high incidence of carcinoma of the nasopharynx among Chinese.
  • In the early stages of the disease, metastases remain confined to the neck.
  • Diagnosis of nasopharyngeal cancer, which tends to occur in relatively young people, should be made by biopsy of the primary tumor.
  • Biopsy of the neck nodes should be avoided because implantation of the tumor in skin and subcutaneous tissue may occur.
  • Radiation therapy is the treatment of choice for the primary nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • Cervical metastases that remain clinically evident should be removed by a radical neck dissection.

questions.text: True statements regarding meningiomas include that they

choices.text: Are treated primarily by surgical excision
Are cured, when properly treated, in nearly 95% of cases e. Arise from the dura

questions.solution:
• Meningiomas are relatively benign tumors that arise from the arachnoid layer of the meninges.
  • They occur predominantly in women (65%) and are treated primarily by surgical excision.
  • Despite their relatively benign nature, the 15- year survival rate for nonmalignant meningiomas is only 68%.

questions.text: Genitourinary tuberculosis in a male patient is suggested by which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
• Genitourinary tuberculosis develops from reactivation of foci in the renal cortex or prostate that were hematogenously seeded during the primary (usually asymptomatic) pulmonary infection.
  • Local spread from the renal and prostatic sites can lead to involvement of the calyx, ureter, bladder, vas deferens, epididymis, and (rarely) the testis.
  • A low-grade inflammatory response results in hematuria or pyuria without bacteriuria.
  • Whenever pus cells are seen on routine urine culture without bacteria on smear or culture plate, genitourinary tuberculosis should be considered.
  • The end result of focal caseation necrosis in the kidney may be scarring and dystrophic calcification.
  • Genital tract infection often causes an asymptomatic swelling in the epididymis; secondary infection or formation of a sinus tract to the scrotal skin may cause more dramatic signs and symptoms.
  • Epididymal tuberculosis is usually managed by chemotherapy, with surgery reserved for refractory cases.
  • Pneumaturia is associated with a colovesical fistula and not with genitourinary tuberculosis.

questions.text: Correct statements concerning antiplatelet therapy include

choices.text: Aspirin has been shown to be an effective antiplatelet agent
Most antiplatelet agents work by enhancing prostaglandin synthesis
Antiplatelet agents have not been shown to increase patency rates of coronary artery bypass grafts
Aspirin can be used to treat deep venous thrombophlebitis

questions.solution:
• Aspirin has an antiplatelet effect that will last for the life of the platelet (approximately 7–10 days).
  • Patients who take aspirin will experience its effect for 7–10 days after stopping the medication.
  • Aspirin interferes with platelet function by inhibiting the synthesis of thromboxane A2, as well as the subsequent production of prostaglandins.
  • The platelet does not have a nucleus and thus cannot remanufacture the prostaglandins necessary for its functioning

questions.text: Conservative management rather than reconstructive arterial surgery is generally recommended for patients with which of the following symptoms or signs of arterial insufficiency?
questions.solution:
• The most important threat to patients with arterial occlusive disease is limb loss.
  • Ischemic ulceration, neuropathy, rest pain, and gangrene represent advanced stages of arterial insufficiency and warrant reconstructive surgery whenever clinically feasible.
  • Claudication, usually, reflects mild ischemia.
  • A vast majority of affected patients are successfully managed without surgery (only 2.5% develop gangrene).
  • Most patients will stabilize or improve with development of increased collateral blood flow with daily exercise, cessation of smoking, and weight loss
  • Vasodilator drugs: have little benefit in the conservative management of intermittent claudication.

questions.text: At the time of operation on a patient, a firm, rubbery lesion in the periphery of the lung is discovered. It is sectioned in the operating room, and reveals tissue that looks like cartilage and smooth muscle. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Hamartoma: tumor arsing from disorganized arrangement of tissues normally found in an organ.
  • Pulmonary hamartomas: are solitary lesions of the pulmonary parenchyma and generally appear as asymptomatic peripheral nodules; they represent the most common benign epithelial and mesodermal elements

questions.text: A 2-year-old asymptomatic child is noted to have a systolic murmur, hypertension, and dimin- ished femoral pulses. Which of the following is true about this child’s disorder?

choices.text: The life expectancy without surgery is about 5 years
Rib notching is often seen on x-ray

questions.solution:
• Coarctation of the aorta: a congenital anomaly that usually causes aortic stenosis just distal to the left subclavian artery in the area of the ligamentum arteriosum.
  • Collateral circulation develops around the obstruction by way of intercostal vessels and accounts for the classic x-ray appearance of rib notching.
  • Without surgery, the average life span is about 30–40 years with eventual death from cardiac failure, rupture of aortic aneurysms or of a cerebral artery, and bacterial endocarditis.
  • Surgery can be accomplished with less than a 1% mortality and should be performed around 5 years of age, when the aorta is sufficiently large to be operable but before it becomes fibrotic and calcified, conditions that increase the technical difficulty of the operation.
  • Claudication is not a common feature of this disorder.
