questions.text: Which of the following complications are expected to develop in a patient who has undergone a total pancreatectomy?
questions.solution:
• The metabolic consequences of total pancreatectomy include weight loss, malabsorption attended by hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia, diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and both iron deficiency and pernicious anemia.
  • The severe metabolic problems that result from total removal of the pancreas make partial pancreaticoduodenectomy a preferred treatment for most cases of pancreatic carcinoma that are resectable.

questions.text: True statements with regards to hemobilia include which one of the following?

choices.text: The classic presentation includes biliary colic, jaundice, and gastrointestinal bleeding
Spontaneous bleeding secondary to hematologic disorders is the major cause of this disorder
Angiography has no role in the treatment of intra-hepatic bleeding
Arterial embolization is advised for hemobilia from the extrahepatic bile ducts

questions.solution:
• The classic Quincke triad: abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, jaundice, and gastrointestinal bleeding is present in 30–40% of patients with hemobilia.
  • Iatrogenic injury has further replaced other trauma as the most common cause of hemobilia.
  • Other causes include spontaneous bleeding during anticoagulation, gallstones, parasitic infections/abscesses, and neoplastic lesions.
  • Endoscopy and angiography and endoscopy are useful diagnostic studies.
  • Intrahepatic bleeding can be controlled by angiographic embolization in up to 95% of cases
  • Surgical treatment is advocated for bleeding from extrahepatic bile ducts or the gallbladder or in cases of penetrating trauma in which associated injuries might need attention

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions is most likely to require surgical correction?
questions.solution:
• Normal respiration creates negative pressure in the thoracic cavity.
  • As a result of the pressure gradient, blood enters the chest via the venae cava and air via the trachea; both are life-sustaining results of this pressure gradient.
  • The pathophysiologic consequence of a hole in the diaphragm is that eventually abdominal viscera will be aspirated into the thorax.
  • A sliding hernia, contained in the lower mediastinum by intact pleura, will rarely cause symptoms of reflux justifying surgical attention, but such patients are in no danger of hollow viscera displacement or vascular compromise

questions.text: A 27 year old man comes with complaints of a rash on his chest. He has no other complaints.the rash is not associated with pain or pruritus. He notices the rash has grown slightly over the past few months. He is homosexual and is in a monogamous relationship but he hasnt got himself tested for HIV. What is the patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
• Kaposi sarcoma is the most common neoplasm associated with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
  • The neoplastic cells contain sequences of a novel virus, HHV-8, which is also known as Kaposi sarcoma–associated herpes virus.
  • In addition to infecting the spindle cells of Kaposi sarcoma, HHV-8 is lymphotropic and has been implicated in two uncommon B-cell lymphoid malignancies, namely, primary effusion lymphoma and multicentric Castleman disease.
  • Like other DNA viruses, the HHV-8 genome encodes proteins that interfere with the p53 and pRb tumor suppressor pathways.
  • Diagnosis: Kaposi sarcoma

questions.text:
A 50 year old man talks about changes in the appearance of his skin. He says he has developed thick skin on his hands and face. Sometimes, vesicles and bullae are formed which rupture and there are moist erosions that heal slowly afterward. There has been an increase in hair growth in these areas as well. He was diagnosed with hepatitis C infection which he seemed to have cleared spontaneously 2 years ago.
What is the cause of the rash?
questions.solution:
• Characteristic, possibly pathognomonic cutaneous features of dermatomyositis: Heliotrope, Gottron papules.
  • Characteristic but not pathognomonic features of dermatomyositis:
  1. Malar erythema, poikiloderma in a photosensitive distribution
  2. Violaceous erythema on the extensor surfaces, and periungual and cuticular changes
  3. Flat, red rash involving the face and upper trunk or other body surfaces, including knees, elbows, neck, anterior chest (i.e. v sign), or back and shoulders (i.e. shawl sign)
  • Lupus can present with facial rashes but the periorbital involvement seen here is more associated with dermatomyositis.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis and scleroderma are not distinctly associated with facial rashes.

questions.text: A 30 year old is on amoxicillin/clavulanic acid for treatment of supposed bacterial sinusitis. 6 days later she presents with a diffuse itchy rash which has not affected her mucous membranes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
DRUG-INDUCED SKIN REACTIONS

  • Most drug-induced skin eruptions are morbilliform (i.e., measles-like) or exanthematous.
  • E.g. penicillins, sulfonamides, phenytoin, or gold will develop a maculopapular eruption.
  • Management of mild cases is aimed at eliminating the offending drug while treating the symptoms.
  • More severe cases require prompt medical attention and treatment with systemic corticosteroids and antihistamines.

Forms of drug eruptions:

  • Exanthematous (erythematous) reactions, or morbilliform (resembling measles) or maculopapular rash.
  • Erythroderma and exfoliative dermatitis
  • Fixed drug eruption
  • Urticaria and angioedema
  • Acniform
  • Psoriasis and psoriasiform eruptions
  • Purpura
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Stevens Johnson syndrome
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Pemphigus-like eruptions
  • Photosensitivity
  • Lichenoid drug eruptions

questions.text: A patient presents to the Dermatology clinic with acne vulgaris is seeking treatment with isotretinoin. Her acne has been resistant to oral antibiotics and topical treatment. You counsel her regarding the teratogenic effects of this medication. Which other side effect should she be aware of with isotretinoin for the treatment of acne vulgaris?
questions.solution:
n:
Agent Class Route Frequency Adverse Events
Acitretin Retinoid Oral Daily
  • Teratogenicity
  • Osteophyte formation
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Flare of inflammatory bowel disease
  • Hepatoxicity
  • Depression

questions.text: True statements about discharge from the nipple include

choices.text: Intermittent thin or milky discharge can be physiologic
Bloody discharge is indicative of an underlying malignancy
Expressible nipple discharge serves as an indication for open biopsy
Galactorrhea is indicative of an underlying malignancy

questions.solution:
• Nipple discharge from the breast can be classified as pathologic, physiologic, or galactorrhea.
  • Galactorrhea: may be due to hormonal imbalance (hyperprolactinemia, hypothyroidism), , trauma to the chest, drugs (oral contraceptives, phenothiazines, antihypertensives, tranquilizers).
  • Physiologic nipple discharge: intermittent, nonlactational (usually serous), and due to stimulation of the nipple or to drugs (estrogens, tranquilizers).
  • Both galactorrhea and physiologic discharge: , arise from multiple ducts, frequently bilateral
  • Pathologic nipple discharge: possibly caused by benign lesions of the breast (duct ectasia, papilloma, fibrocystic disease) or by cancer; may be bloody, serous, or gray-green. Usually spontaneous and unilateral and can often be localized to a single nipple duct

questions.text: A 20 year old woman with Turner’s syndrome is diagnosed with Hypertension. On further examination, her femoral pulses are delayed as compared to carotid pulses. On auscultation, there was a mid to late systolic murmur. What is the most likely radiological finding?

choices.text: An 8 sign due to modelling deformities of the major thoracic blood vessels
An enlarged external mammary artery on a lateral plain chest x ray

questions.solution:
• Coarctation of the aorta is associated with inferior rib notching.
  • It takes 3-10 years to develop
  • This causes hypertension and often produces left ventricular hypertrophy
  • The first two ribs are usually spared due to intercostal arteries, they are supplied via the costo-cervical trunk proximal to the coarctation and they therefore do not contribute to the collateral circulation

questions.text: Which of the following strongly suggests the diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
• Essential to the diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism is the finding of hypercalcemia.
  • With rare exceptions, operations for primary hyperparathyroidism should not be performed unless the patient is hypercalcemic.
  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is not invariably elevated, but it should be elevated relative to the serum calcium level.
  • Ordinarily, high serum calcium levels suppress parathyroid secretion.
  • Therefore, in the presence of hypercalcemia, normal levels of PTH are “abnormal.”
  • Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism: either normal or elevated urinary calcium. Patients with familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) have hypercalcemia

questions.text: A 59 year old woman with rheumatoid arthritis presents with flu-like symptoms. She also has a non-productive cough. She was put on a round of broad spectrum antibodies, to no effect. An HRCT is ordered, which shows widespread mosaic perfusion in the lungs. How can you differentiate between obliterative bronchiolitis rather than diffuse pulmonary hemorrhage?

choices.text: Reduced pulmonary vessel calibre in the hyperattenuated area
Reduced pulmonary vessel calibre in the hypoattenuated area
Normal pulmonary vessel calibre in the hyperattenuated area
Increased pulmonary vessel calibre in the hypoattenuated area

questions.solution:
• Obliterative bronchiolitis is described as bronchiolar and peribronchial inflammation affecting the membranous and respiratory bronchioles
  • All affected areas display decreased attenuation as a result of trapping of air and decreased perfusion relative to normal areas

questions.text: When galactorrhea occurs in a high school student, a diagnostic associated finding would be
questions.solution:
• Prolactin-secreting tumors in the pituitary gland (previously called chromophobe adenomas) may grow to large size and cause bitemporal hemianopia because of prox- imity to the optic chiasm.
  • They are typically associated with amenorrhea and galactorrhea (the “A/G syndrome”) in women.
  • In both sexes, lack of libido and impotence or infertility may be noted.
  • Removal of the adenomas ensures restoration of sexual vigor.
  • These tumors are not life threatening; if their physical size is not an issue or the relative sexual dysfunction is not a problem, benign neglect is sometimes recommended

questions.text: A cross-match is performed by incubating

choices.text: Donor serum with recipient lymphocytes and complement
Donor lymphocytes with recipient serum and complement
Recipient serum with a known panel of multiple donor lymphocytes

questions.solution:
• The purpose of a cross-match is to determine whether the recipient has circulating antibodies against donor HLA antigens.
  • These antibodies do not occur naturally, but rather are the result of prior sensitization during pregnancy, blood transfusions, or previous transplantation.
  • A complement-dependent lymphocytotoxicity cross-match is performed by adding recipient serum and complement to donor cells (T cells, B cells, or monocytes).
  • If specific anti- donor antibodies are present, antibody binding results in complement fixation and cell lysis.
  • This is detected by addition of a vital dye, which is taken up by the damaged cell membrane, resulting in a positive cross- match.
  • If a positive cross-match is detected to donor T cells (HLA class I), transplantation will result in hyperacute rejection

questions.text: Rapid fluid resuscitation of the hypovolemic patient after abdominal trauma is significantly enhanced by which of the following?

choices.text: Placement of long 18-gauge subclavian vein catheters
Placement of percutaneous femoral vein catheters
Placement of short, large-bore percutaneous peripheral intravenous catheters

questions.solution:
• Rapid fluid administration is often the key to successful trauma resuscitation.
  • Factors affecting the rate of fluid resuscitation include the diameter of the intravenous tubing, the size and length of the venous cannulae, the fluid viscosity, and the site of administration.
  • According to Poiseuille’s law, flow is proportional to the fourth power of the radius of a catheter and inversely proportional to its length.
  • Therefore, the shorter a catheter and the larger its diameter, the faster one can infuse a solution through it.
  • Central venous placement alone does not assure rapid flow.
  • Importantly, the diameter of the intravenous tubing employed may be the rate-determining factor in fluid delivery: blood-infusion tubing allows twice the flow of standard intravenous tubing and should be used when rapid fluid resuscitation is needed.
  • Any patient who is suspected of having a major abdominal injury should immediately have at least two short, large-bore (16-gauge or larger) intravenous cannulae placed in peripheral veins.
  • Longer, smaller catheters, such as standard 18-gauge central venous catheters, may take more time to place and will have lower flow rates.
  • Once fluid resuscitation is under way, one may elect to place an 8- or 9-French pulmonary artery catheter-introducer via a central venous approach for further volume administration, as well as for measurement of central venous pressure or for Swan-Ganz catheter insertion.
  • Lower-extremity venous cannulae, placed by saphenous vein cutdown or percutaneously into the femoral veins, are no longer advised as primary access for patients with abdominal trauma, since possible disruption of iliac veins or the inferior vena cava will render volume infusion ineffective.
  • Studies have demonstrated that the flow rate of cold whole blood is roughly two-thirds that of whole blood at room temperature.
  • Diluting and warming the blood by “piggybacking” it into infusion lines that are delivering crystalloid will decrease the blood’s viscosity, enhance flow, and minimize hypothermia.

questions.text: A 3-year-old man complains of 1 week of dizziness, vertigo, tinnitus, and right-sided gait ataxia. Electronystagmography (calorics) with sequential administration of warm and cold water into the ear canal is performed. On the left, cold water causes right-beating nystagmus and warm water causes left-beating nystagmus. On the right ear, there is no response to the cold caloric. What is the cause of this patient’s dizziness and vertigo?
questions.solution:
• In the acute evaluation of vertigo, vestibular function tests can help to establish the side of the abnormality and differentiate between central and peripheral etiologies.
  • When performing electronystagmography using cold and warm water sequentially, the velocity of the slow-phase of nystagmus is compared from side to side.
  • When warm water at 44°C is infused into an ear, the normal response is nystagmus with the fast component toward the infused ear.
  • The opposite response occurs when cold water at 30°C is infused; the normal response is nystagmus with the fast component away from the cold water–infused ear.
  • The volume of water can be increased if no response occurs with the initial attempt.
  • Velocity of the slow phase should be similar in patients without vestibular nerve abnormalities.
  • An absence of response to the cold caloric indicates a labyrinth system that is “dead” and nonfunctional, such as in complete destruction of the neural input with acoustic neuroma.
  • Otoconia are not a result of and do not cause peripheral nerve dysfunction. The caloric testing is normal in patients with otoconia.
  • The peripheral nerve dysfunction seen with aminoglycoside antibiotics is usually bilateral. Unilateral symptoms should raise the suspicion for an anatomic as opposed to a systemic cause of the vertigo.
  • Labyrinthine ischemia will also manifest as a “dead” labyrinth; however, the patient’s age makes ischemic brainstem lesions less likely than a schwannoma

questions.text: A 72 year old man with increasing hoarseness and difficulty swallowing solids comes to the OPD. He has a history of smoking for the past 10 years and also tobacco ingestion. He is suspected to have laryngeal carcinoma limited to the supraglottis. All of the following supraglottic subsites are affected by the disease except:
questions.solution:
The aryepiglottic fold consists of oblique arytenoid muscle , the thyroarytenoid muscle the cuneiform and corniculate cartilages Out of which Aryepiglottic folds with the cuneiform and corniculate cartilages are the only subsites of the supraglottic carcinoma of larynx

Sites Subsites
Supraglottic

Suprahyoid epiglottis Infrahyoid epiglottis ArytenoidsAryepiglottic folds with the cuneiform and corniculatecartilages Vestibular fold

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding spasmodic dysphonia?

choices.text: It’s only a local laryngeal disorder
In the Adductor type, the voice becomes strangled
In the adductor type, the spasm of the cricoarytenoid muscle causes the glottis to be kept open

questions.solution:
• Spasmodic Dysphonia is not just a local laryngeal disorder as it also affects the neurological System too
  • Bufotoxin is a toxin derived from the local toad which is not of use in this condition
  • Botulinum toxin is instead used which is injected in the muscle fold for best results
  • In the adductor type, the spasm of the adductor muscles like lateral cricoarytenoid and transverse arytenoid go into spasm causing the vocal cords to go into adduction
  • This in turn causes the voice to be strained or appear strangled
  • In the adductor type, There is spasm of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle causing the glottis to be kept open
  • Hence the voice appears more breathy in the adductor type of spasmodic dysphonia
  • Botulinum toxin is also used for treatment in this type of dysphonia

questions.text: A 27 year old man presented to the clinic with difficulty in breathing. On examination a painless, nasopharyngeal mass was detected which made a suspicion of Angiofibroma. Which of the following statements about Angiofibroma is not true?

choices.text: It’s a benign tumor with no local invasion
It arises from the sphenopalatine foramen and the investigation of choice for diagnosis is HRCT
The tumour is said to be testosterone dependent

questions.solution:
• Angiofibroma is a benign but a locally aggressive tumour
  • It arises from the sphenopalatine foramen
  • The tumour is most commonly seen in adolescent males in the second decade of life
  • The tumour starts with a hamartomatousnidus with a vascular origin in the nasopharynx which is activated when the male sex hormones appear and increase in the body, the nidus is converted into an Angiofibroma
  • HRCT Is investigation of choice as it helps to visualise all the borders of the tumour
  • Since it’s a highly vascular tumour, biopsy is contraindicated

questions.text: A 23 year old man comes to the ER with a two day history of severe epigastric pain which is accompanied by vomiting. The pain has seemed to increase a lot in duration and quantity as well. He has been constipated since then but he has passed flatus. The patient is usually in a good condition with no history of any disease. But he consumes 150 units of alcohol per week. Upon further investigations, his White blood cell count is elevated along with serum amylase levels. Abdominal x-ray showed a single small bowel segment dilatation in the central abdominal region. Identify the image associated with this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Acute Pancreatitis

  • X-ray signs of acute pancreatitis
    • Sentinel loop signQ (single dilated small bowel loop), optimally demonstrated in left lateral decubitus view.
    • Renal halo signQ (the left kidney has surrounding halo due to edema and is displaced down).
    • Colonic ‘cut-off’ signQ (dilated transverse colon becomes abruptly gasless in the region of splenic flexure)
    • “Gasless abdomen” due to vomiting
    • Left pleural effusion
  • Pneumoperitoneum signs-
    • Football sign" = large pneumoperitoneum outlining entire abdominal cavity "Double wall sign" = "Rigler sign" = air on both sides of bowel as intraluminal gas and free air outside (usually requires >1,000 mL of free intraperitoneal gas + intraperitoneal fluid)
  • 'Sigmoid volvulus' is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on its mesentery, the sigmoid mesocolon.
  • BIRD OF PREY SIGN

Tapered barium column seen in SIGMOID VOLVULUS

questions.text: A 12 year old girl from a rural area entered the PHC with nasal discharge which was extremely foul smelling. She complained of recurrent epistaxis and on examination there was a lot of nasal crusting present. In addition there was also the presence of maggots in the nasal cavity. All of the following can be used in the treatment of the same except:

choices.text: All visible maggots should be extracted by forceps

questions.solution:
• Maggots in the Nasal Cavity is also known as Myiasis
  • It’s a complication of Atrophic rhinitis most commonly seen in rural areas and areas with less hygienic conditions
  • Maggots get attracted to foul smelling discharge and unclean habits Treatment:
  • All visible maggots should be removed by forceps
  • Instillation of diluted chloroform with water
  • Nasal douching with warm saline is used to remove nasal crusts and dead maggots Systemic antibiotics have no role in treatment

questions.text: True about EFFECTIVE DOSE:

choices.text: used to estimate the non-biologic effects of radiation and is expressed in millisieverts (mSv).
used to estimate the non-biologic effects of radiation and is expressed in centigray (cGy)
used to estimate the biologic effects of radiation and is expressed in centigray (cGy).
used to estimate the biologic effects of radiation and is expressed in millisieverts (mSv).

questions.solution: The effective dose is a measure used to estimate the biologic effects of radiation and is expressed in millisieverts (mSv). - Effective dose is the product of the equivalent dose multiplied by a tissue weighting factor, summed for all organs and tissues in the body. It is not always the same as the dose area product

questions.text: A 39 year old man with a previous history of Ménière’s disease presented to the ER with a history of sudden fall while standing in the kitchen without loss of consciousness. On arrival the patient had no focal deficit, his cardiovascular signs were also within normal range. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical vignette is suggestive of Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis
  • It is also known as drop attacks, where the patient with a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness
  • The pathogenesis is still unclear

Tulio phenomenon

  • It’s a condition in which loud sounds usually is following by syncopal attacks associated with vertigo

Lermoyez syndrome

1. Here the symptoms of Meniere’s are seen in reverse order

questions.text: A 24 year old man comes to the OPD with complaints of swelling of his right knee which is increasing progressively. He got the injury following a football match some weeks ago. A radiograph was ordered which showed a 6 cm ill-defined lytic lesion within the right distal femoral metaphysis. There is a permeative pattern of bone loss and there were areas of ossifications with a cloud like appearance. Furthermore, there is a periosteal reaction, mostly focused perpendicular to the cortex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteosarcoma is the most common radiation induced tumor.

Osteosarcoma: Cancer of Young AKA Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cell. It is the 2nd MC primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. Osteosarcoma may be more common in patients with the hereditary form of retinoblastoma and Li-Fraumeni syndrome. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Almost all patients with high-grade osteosarcoma report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis; however, only about 25% of patients experience this phenomenon.

X-ray knee

Codman's triangle is a Periosteal reaction that might take the form of Codman's triangle, or it may have a sunburst or hair on end appearance. MRI is most useful to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue).

questions.text: A 44 year old female comes to the OPD with a past medical history of shoulder pain accompanied with stiffness. Now the pain has flared up more intensely even at night times. She denies any trauma to her shoulder or any other illness per say. Upon further investigations, she has decreased active and passive range of motion. All of the conditions are associated with frozen shoulders except?
questions.solution:
Psoriasis has no association with Frozen shoulder

  • Frozen shoulder is a clinical condition of the shoulder characterized by limited range of motion resulting in progressive pain and stiffness
  • It mainly occurs due to inflammation of the glenoid capsule which causes increases adhesions and fibrosis from within resulting in limited range of motion
  • It's more common in females aged > 40 years
  • It mostly resolves spontaneously after 15-18 months
  • Associated conditions include:
  1. Diabetes mellitus
  2. hyperthyroidism
  3. Ischemic stroke or myocardial infarction
  4. trauma/ prolonged immobilization
  5. Duputryen’s disease

questions.text:
A 24 year old fitness trainer who regularly lifts heavy weights and works out more than 2 hours per day presented to the clinic with complaints of inability to squat, associated pain as and when he tries to squat or any other leg exercises. He has a history of regular intake of steroids and creatine over the last few months. His x ray is given below:

What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of head of femur
Fracture of posterior lip of the acetabulum

questions.solution:
Etiopathogenesis

  • Idiopathic (most common)—Called as Chandeliers Disease'

Avascular Necrosis of head of femur causes:

  • Trauma - Neck of femur fracture, Posterior dislocation of hip. (>12-hour duration)
  • Substance: Alcohol, steroid use. Infection: Septic arthritis, osteomyelitis
  • Storage disorders: Gaucher’s disease
  • Caisson disease: Dysbaric osteonecrosis (Nitrogen accumulates)
  • Hemoglobinopathy and Coagulation disorder: Sickle cell disease, Familial thrombophilia A. Hypofibrinolysis, Hypolipoproteinemia.

Fig. Region of femoral head affected in AVN

  • Congenital disorders- Perthes disease, Slipped capital femoral epiphysis.
  • Hematological malignancies- Leukemia, lymphoma, polycythemia.
  • Hyperlipidemia- Nephrotic syndrome
  • Other- SLE, ionising radiation, Pregnancy, pancreatitis, Amyloid, Renal failure and dialysis, Hyperparathyroid­ism.
  • History of intake of steroids usually results in avascular necrosis. The causes of hip AVN includes excess alcohol consumption and the use of corticosteroids.
  • The classic appearance of a thin subchondral fracture line known as “Crescent sign”. It is seen on X -ray signifies Avascular necrosis.
  • Most common location of AVN is the Head of Femur which is called Chandelier’s sign.

questions.text: A 22 year old man comes to the OPD with severe back pain, fever and unintentional weight loss for the past month. On a physical exam, he has a kyphotic deformity present on his back. What is not true about the management of Pott’s paraplegia?

choices.text: Paraplegia not improving with conservative treatment even after 3–6 weeks is an indication for operative intervention
Posterior decompression and instrumentation can be used to correct the deformity
Chemotherapy is the mainstay of conservative management
Decompression via anterolateral approach is most preferred

questions.solution:
• Posterior structures like the lamina are not removed because disease destroys anteriorly and if the surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.

Management of Pott’s paraplegia:

  • Chemotherapy is the mainstay of conservative management
  • Paraplegia not improving with conservative treatment even after 3–6 weeks is an indication for operative intervention
  • Most preferred procedure:
  1. Anterolateral decompression + bone grafting
  2. Anterior decompression + bone grafting
  • Posterior approach should never be preferred as it can damage the posterior elements of the spine.

questions.text: Rinne’s test showed positive result on left side and negative result on right side & Weber’s test showed lateralization to left side in a 38-year-old male who came with a c/o of decrease in hearing ability. Your probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Rinne’s Test

  • Negative on right side means either there is:

- Conductive deafness of Right side or

- Severe SNHL on right side (leading to false negative Rinne test)

  • To differentiate between the 2 conditions: Let us see the result of Weber’s test:

- Patient is complaining of decreased hearing in the right ear and Weber’s test is lateralized to the left ear (as stated in the question) i.e. to the better ear.

- Weber’s test is lateralized to the better ear in case of SNHL. So, diagnosis is right sided severe SNHL.

Remember: If Rinne’s test is negative and Weber’s test shows lateralization toward healthy side, it indicates severe SNHL

questions.text: All of the following are features of Mongoloid definition except:
questions.solution:
• Carabelli’s tubercle is an anomalous cusp on the mesial palatal surface of the upper first permanent molars, most commonly seen among caucasians.

Shovel incisors:

  • They are Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface

Carbelli’s cusp

  • Small additional nodule on lingual surface of maxillary molar

Taurodontism (Bull tooth)

  • The pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep
  • The roots are fused and bent.

questions.text: IPC section 85 states that:

choices.text: Child under 7 years is not liable for act
A person of unsound mind s not liable for the act
A person who is under involuntary intoxication and commits a crime is not liable for the act
A person who is under voluntary intoxication and commits a crime is liable for the act.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct about the use of this given instrument?

1) Harvesting Temporalis fascia
2) Self-retaining and hemostatic.
3) In mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision
4) Helps in removal of bone
questions.solution:
Mollison's mastoid retractor

  • Self-retaining mastoid retractor with four prongs on either blade

USES-

  • Harvesting Temporalis fascia
  • Used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps
  • It is self-retaining and hemostatic

Mastoid Gouge -Helps in the removal of bone

  • Perkin's mastoid retractor has 1×3 prongs

questions.text: All of the following are tests for cessation of respiration except:
questions.solution:
Tests for confirming cessation of circulation are :

  1. Magnus test (ligature test): Fingers fail to show congestion and swelling to a ligature applied at their base.
  2. Diaphanous test (transillumination test): Failure to show redness in finger web spaces on transillumination from behind
  3. Icard's test: Failure to produce yellowish green discoloration of skin on injection of fluorescein dye.
  4. Fingernail test: No blanching and filling of blood on applying pressure and release of pressure.

Tests for confirming cessation of respiration are :

  1. Feather test: There is No movement of feather if held in front of nose.
  2. Mirror test: Mirror held in front of nose does not show vapors and blurring.
  3. Winslow's test: No movement of reflection of light shone on mirror/surface water in bowel, kept on chest.

questions.text: You receive the body of a 38- year-old male for autopsy. During the procedure you are seeing the finding as shown in the image below. The following appearance is seen at what range?
questions.solution:
The injury shown in this image is a characteristics shotgun wound

  • There is a central round hole with multiple pellets holes scattered around the central hole.
  • This wound is most likely to have been caused by a shotgun from a range of 1-5 m.

questions.text: Identify the wrong pair with the condition and its appropriate colour of Post mortem staining:
questions.solution:
Condition Colour of Post mortem staining
Usual colour Reddish purple
CO Cherry red
HCN Bright Red or Dark Red or Brick Red

CO2, Asphyxia, Aniline Deep blue (In Aniline Deep blue as well as Red Brown colour can occur)
