questions.text: A 30 year old female complains of lower extremity weakness for the last 5 days. She says there has been progressive weakness with loss of sensation starting below the belly button and she is also experiencing urinary incontinence. Past medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination shows a sensory level at the level of the umbilicus. The lower extremities show strength bilaterally proximally and distally. Reflexes, cerebellar examinations are normal. All the following are appropriate steps in evaluating this patient except
questions.solution:
• This patient’s clinical scenario is consistent with myelopathy. The rapidity of onset and the lack of other antecedent symptoms (e.g., pain) make a non compressive etiology most likely.
  • An MRI is the initial test of choice and will easily identify a structural lesion such as a neoplasm or subluxation.
  • Non Compressive myelopathies result from five basic causes: spinal cord infarction; systemic disorders such as vasculitis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and sarcoidosis; infections (particularly viral); demyelinating disease such as multiple sclerosis; and idiopathic.
  • Therefore, serologies for antinuclear antibodies, viral serologies such as HIV and HTLV I, and lumbar puncture are all indicated.
  • Because the clinical scenario is consistent with myelopathy, an electromyogram is not indicated

questions.text: The toxic principle of this plant is:-
questions.solution:
Mayapple (May Apple)

  • Other Common Names: American Mandrake.
  • Toxic Principle : Podophyllin (purified form: podophyllotoxin):

Clinical Features

  1. Exposure of the eyes to podophyllum powder causes intense irritation with conjunctivitis, keratitis, corneal ulceration, and iritis.
  2. Ingestion results in nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting,and diarrhoea, followed by fever, tachypnoea, peripheral neuropathy, tachycardia, hypotension, ataxia, dizziness,lethargy, confusion, and altered sensorium.

questions.text: On a neurologic consultation , you are asked to evaluate a patient with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy syndrome. The patient has a history of intractable complex partial seizures that rarely generalize. Her seizures often begin with an aura and commonly manifest as behavioral arrests and unilateral posturing. On further examination, MRI reveals small temporal lobes and a small hippocampus. Which of these is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Complex partial seizures are characterized by focal seizure activity plus impairment of the patient’s ability to maintain contact with the environment.
  • Mesial temporal lobe epilepsy is syndrome associated with complex partial seizures.
  • Patients are unable to respond to verbal or visual commands during the seizure and they often manifest complex automatisms or complex posturing.
  • An aura is common before the seizures.
  • There is postictal memory loss or disorientation.
  • Patients present with a history of febrile seizures or a family history of seizures.
  • MRI will show hippocampal sclerosis, a small temporal lobe, or enlarged temporal horn.
  • Hypothyroidism, herpes virus infection, diabetes, and tuberous sclerosis are not associated with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy

questions.text: A 66 year old man comes to the OPD with his wife. She says that over the past 2 months he’s had slowed thinking and a changed personality in the sense that he’s very withdrawn. The patient's history is negligible except a mild but persistent headache which is diffuse. There is no past family history of neurological disorders or psychiatric disorders. A mini mental examination score is 18/30. His head CT is shown in Figure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The head CT shows bilateral hypodense fluid collections in the subdural space. Subdural Hematoma (acute)SDH accumulates in the space between dura and arachnoid. Disruption of the cortical vessel or brain laceration . Almost always associated with a significant primary brain injury . Patients most commonly present with an impaired conscious level from the time of injury, but further deterioration can occur as the hematoma expands. CT appearance SDH : Hyperdense (acute blood) concave appearance. Treatment of SDH : evacuation via craniotomy. Small hematomas with little mass effect may be managed conservatively in neurosurgical centres Mortality rate from SDH is much higher than for EDH and is as high as 40% in some series

questions.text: A 21 year old woman is brought to the emergency department after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure confirmed by bystanders. She has no identifying information on herself , and her past medical history is unknown. What is the most likely cause of her seizure?
questions.solution: Adolescence and early adulthood mark the period where idiopathic or genetic epilepsy syndromes become less common and seizures due to acquired CNS lesions become more common. The MCC of seizures in the young adults are head trauma, central nervous system (CNS) infections, brain tumors, congenital CNS lesions, illicit drug use, or alcohol withdrawal. Fever rarely causes seizures in patients >12 years. Amyloid angiopathy and uremia are more common in older adults

questions.text: CLED medium is used in the preference to MacConkey agar in relation to culture of organisms involved in urine infection. The reason is

choices.text: Differentiates Lactose Forming and Non- Lactose Forming

questions.solution:
• This is similar to MacConkey agar, differentiating between LF and NLF.
  • It is used as an alternative to combination of blood agar and MacConkey agar, for the processing of urine specimens.
  • Advantages over MacConkey agar: It is less inhibitory than MacConkey agar, supports the growth of gram-positive bacteria (except β hemolytic Streptococcus) and Candida.
  • Advantage over blood agar: It can prevent the swarming of Proteus.

questions.text: A 64 year old male presents with severe right sided eye and facial pain, nausea, vomiting, colored halos around lights, and loss of visual acuity. His right eye is quite red, and that pupil is dilated and fixed. Which of the following diagnostic tests would confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution: This patient has acute angle-closure glaucoma resulting from obstruction of the outflow of aqueous humor at the iris. The buildup of intraocular pressure can be confirmed by measurement and requires urgent treatment with hyperosmotic agents. Permanent treatment requires laser or surgical iridotomy. Angle closure glaucoma is less common than primary open-angle glaucoma, which is asymptomatic and is usually detectable only through measurements of intraocular pressure at a routine eye examination

questions.text: True regarding thymus is:

choices.text: Mature thymocytes express CD 4 and CD 8
Thymocytes whose T-cell receptor bind with high affinity to self-antigens and MHC Complexes are clonally deleted
Mature thymocytes express surface IgM and IgD
CD 4 and CD 8 double positive cells are completely eliminated by a process of negative selection.

questions.solution:
• CD 4 and CD 8 double positive (DP) T-cells are not eliminated completely.
  • They have three fates:
  • Positive selection: The 5% of DP T-cells, whose αβ receptors are capable of recognizing their MHC molecules are positively selected. This results in MHC restriction.
  • Death by neglect: Majority of DP cells (95%) fail positive selection because they do not specifically recognize their MHC molecules.
  • Negative selection: The survived cells that undergo positive selection (5%) are MHC restricted.
  • However, some of these surviving cells (2–5%) react to the self antigens and therefore, they are selected to be killed by apoptosis and removed (negatively selection).
  • The remaining DP T-cells (2–5%) having αβ type TCR selectively loose either CD4 or CD8 and become single positive mature T-cells
  • Mature thymocytes are single positive; i.e. they express either CD 4 or CD 8; but never both.
  • Mature B cells (not thymocytes) express surface IgM and IgD.

questions.text: A 33 year old male with a past medical history of end stage renal disease is currently on hemodialysis. He was on a stable hemodialysis regimen for 8 years, and all his electrolytes are normal. He is having complaints of decreased libido, inability to maintain erections and mild weakness. Further examination reveals a decrease in serum testosterone level. Measurement of which of the following will distinguish primary from secondary hypogonadism?
questions.solution: Measurement of luteinizing hormone (LH) or follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) will distinguish primary from secondary hypogonadism in men with reduced serum testosterone levels. Elevations in LH and FSH suggest primary gonadal dysfunction, whereas normal or reduced LH and FSH suggest a central hypothalamic pituitary defect. Patients with chronic illness such as HIV, end-stage renal disease, COPD, and cancer and patients receiving chronic corticosteroids have a high frequency of hypogonadism that is associated with muscle wasting. There are some reports of reversal of hypogonadism in patients with end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis after a renal transplant

questions.text: Phylum Apicomplexa contains-
questions.solution:
Phylum apicomplexa contains the non-motile protozoa-Plasmodium, Isospora, Toxoplasma, Babesia, Cyclospora and Cryptosporidium.

Phylum Sarcomastigophora- has 2 subphyla.

Subphylum - Mastigophora: movement with flagella - e.g. Trichomonas, Giardia, Leishmania

Subphylum - Sarcodina: pseudopodia, e.g. Entamoeba

Phylum Ciliophora: Movement with cilia, e.g. Balantidium.

Phylum Microspora: e.g. Enterocytozoon

questions.text: Flagella are microscopic hair-like structures involved in the locomotion of a cell. Which of the following is a motile organism?
questions.solution:
Motility is due to flagella (flagellin).

  1. Monotrichous- Vibrio cholera
  2. Amphitrichous- Alcaligenes faecalis
  3. Lophotrichous- Spirillum minus
  4. Peritrichous- E.coli, Proteus, Listeria, salmonella

Yersinia pestis, Shigella dysentery, Salmonella pullorum are all non-motile organisms

questions.text: A 24 year old woman presents with 2 weeks of nausea, vomiting, and jaundice. She has been previously healthy and has no past medical history. On examination, a palpable liver edge is appreciated. Ocular findings are shown in the image. Her transaminases and total bilirubin are elevated. Which of the following tests will lead to a definitive diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assa

questions.solution:
• This patient is suspected to have Wilson disease, based on clinical presentation and the visible Kayser-Fleischer ring seen in this image.
  • The “goldstandard” for diagnosis is liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays. Kayser-Fleischer rings can be diagnosed definitively only with a slit-lamp examination and are highly specific for the disease: they are present in >99% of patients who have concomitant neuropsychiatric manifestations of copper toxicity and in 30–50% of patients with liver involvement alone or who are presymptomatic.
  • They do not cause visual impairment.
  • Total iron-binding capacity and ferritin will be abnormal in hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A patient with AIDS had an acute episode of diarrhea. The stool examination revealed an oval structure (8 to 9ù in diameter) that was acid-fast and fluorescent blue under ultraviolet light. The most likely identification of this organism is?
questions.solution:
Acid fast structures that autofluoresce under UV light suggests the coccidian protozoa as the cause of the diarrhea.

The size of 8-9 microns helps to arrive at the answer of Cyclospora.

⇒ Cyclospora, Cystoisospora and Cryptosporidium are coccidian protozoa that cause opportunistic intestinal infections in HIV patients.

Image below: Cryptosporidium

Image below: cyclospora

questions.text: A 16 year old presents to the ER with a headache which has worsened since the past 2 months. His parents said that he has been perfectly fine until this incident and that since then he hasn’t seemed like himself and over the past 2 weeks he has complained of double vision. He had an episode of profuse vomiting this afternoon, which prompted his visit. He also describes weight gain over the same 2 month time period and has not been sleeping well. On examination, he is drowsy, and a funduscopic examination reveals papilledema. He has no fever, neck stiffness, or elevated white blood cell count. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Craniopharyngiomas are benign suprasellar cystic masses that typically present with headaches, visual field deficits, and hypopituitarism.
  • They arise near the pituitary stalk and extend into the suprasellar cistern. They are most common in children and often present with signs of increased intracranial pressure.
  • More than half present before the age of 20. Weight gain, cognitive changes, sleep disorders, and visual field defects are common.
  • Hypopituitarism is present in 90% of cases, and diabetes insipidus in 10% of cases. MRI is the test of choice for evaluation.
  • Definitive management includes transcranial or transsphenoidal surgical resection followed by radiation.
  • Meningioma should appear on the differential of the patient above; epidemiologically, these tumors are MC in women more than men, and tend to occur between the ages of 40 and 70.
  • Congenital panhypopituitarism would not explain his acute worsening nor his increased intracranial pressure.
  • Carney syndrome consists of myxomas; endocrine tumors including adrenal, testicular, and pituitary adenomas; and skin pigmentation

questions.text: A 61 year old woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of hypercalcemia of 12.8 mg/dL which was an incidental find on a chemistry panel that was done during a hospitalization for cervical trauma which was operated 7 weeks ago. Despite fluid administration in the hospital, her serum calcium at discharge was 11.8 mg/dL. She has no other complaints. On further tests, her serum calcium level is 12.4 mg/dL, and phosphate is 2.3 mg/dL. Her hematocrit and all other chemistries including creatinine were normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hyperparathyroidism is the most common cause of hypercalcemia and is the most likely cause.
  • Cancer is the second most common cause of hypercalcemia but usually is associated with symptomatic hypercalcemia.
  • Immobilization may lead to the bone resorption which is sufficient to cause hypercalcemia.
  • This immobilization is usually caused by spinal cord injury or extensive casting after fractures, although it can occur in settings such as Parkinson’s disease.
  • Hypercalcemia occuring due to immobilization occurs mostly in the young and in patients with other reasons for a high rate of bone turnover for example in paget’s disease or extensive fractures

questions.text: A 62 year old woman arrives at the OPD complaining of fatigue and lethargy over a period of 6 months. She describes dry skin and has noted that she is losing hair. On examination she is mildly bradycardic at 52 beats/min with normal blood pressure and has dry, coarse skin.Which is the most likely clinical diagnosis and which test would be indicated for screening for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The main clinical symptoms of hypothyroidism include tiredness, weakness, dry skin, feeling cold, hair loss, difficulty concentrating, constipation with poor appetite, dyspnea, and hoarse voice.
  • Signs of hypothyroidism include dry coarse skin, puffy hands/face/feet (myxedema), diffuse alopecia, bradycardia, peripheral edema, delayed tendon reflex relaxation, carpal tunnel syndrome, and serous cavity effusions.
  • TSH is the most effective screening test for hypothyroidism. If elevated, an unbound T4 is necessary to confirm clinical hypothyroidism.
  • Testing of unbound T4 will not detect subclinical hypothyroidism.
  • Subclinical hypothyroidism is present when the TSH is elevated and unbound T4 is normal.
  • Patients may have minor or early symptoms of hypothyroidism in this stage

questions.text: A Brazilian immigrant is hired at a meat packing plant and undergoes a physical examination. Chest X-ray shows a patchy bilateral pneumonia and a lung mass. Biopsy of the mass shows fungal organisms with a few very distinctive ‘pilot’s wheel’ yeast forms. What is the most likely diagnosis-
questions.solution:
Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus that is endemic in humid areas of Central and South America, especially inBrazil.

Paracoccidioidomycosis or South American blastomycosis develops after the inhalation of aerosolized conidia encountered in the environment.

A presumptive diagnosis can be made by detection of the distinctive thick-walled yeast, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferentially in purulent material or in tissue biopsies. The yeast form looks like pilot-wheel or mariner’s wheel.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents to the clinic for a routine health examination. A comprehensive metabolic panel shows a serum calcium level of 11.2 mg/dL. Serum phosphate is 3.0 mg/dL. Serum creatinine is normal. He denies bone pain, lethargy, weakness, or weight loss. What is the MC cause of hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
• Primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy account for over 90% of cases of hypercalcemia. In asymptomatic patients, primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common cause. In patients admitted to the hospital with symptomatic hypercalcemia, malignancy is the most common cause.
  • Calcium is regulated in bone, the gastrointestinal tract, and the kidney.
  • Other causes of increased bone turnover include Paget’s disease, immobilization, hyperthyroidism, hypervitaminosis A, and adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 27 year old female with SLE is in remission and her treatment currently is azathioprine 70 mg/d and prednisone 5 mg/d. Previous year she had a life-threatening exacerbation of the disease. She now wants to get pregnant. Which among the following is the least appropriate advice?

choices.text: Advise her about high risk of spontaneous abortion
Warn her that exacerbations may occur in the first trimester and also in the postpartum period.
Inform her that it is unlikely that the newborn will have lupus.
Stop the prednisone just before she attempts to become pregnant.

questions.solution:
• Many clinicians believe that females with SLE should not become pregnant if they have active disease or advanced renal or cardiac disease, the presence of SLE itself is not an absolute contraindication to pregnancy.
  • The outcome of pregnancy is best for females who are in remission at the time of conception.
  • Even in females with quiescent disease, exacerbations may occur (usually in the first trimester and the immediate postpartum period), and 25 to 40% of these pregnancies end in spontaneous abortion.
  • Fetal loss rates are higher in patients with lupus anticoagulant or anticardiolipin antibodies.
  • Steroids given throughout pregnancy also usually have no adverse effects on the child. In this case, the fact that the female had a life-threatening bout of disease a year ago would argue against stopping her drugs at this time.
  • Neonatal lupus, which is manifested by thrombocytopenia, rash, and heart block, is rare but can occur when mothers have anti-Ro antibodies

questions.text: A 48 year old male has a long-standing history of ankylosing spondylitis. His most recent spinal film shows straightening of the lumbar spine, loss of lordosis, and “squaring” of the vertebral bodies. He currently is limited by pain with ambulation that is not improved with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications. Which of these treatments has been shown to improve symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Before the introduction of anti-tumor necrosis factor (TNF) α therapy, the mainstay of treatment for ankylosing spondylitis was nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and exercise therapy
  • MRI findings in patients treated with these agents also show marked improvement in marrow edema, enthesitis, and joint effusions. ?-?
  • The long-term effects of these agents are not known.
  • Other treatments for AS can be used, including NSAIDs and COX-2 inhibitors, to decrease pain, especially in mild cases.

questions.text: A 30-years-old male presented with discrete hypopigmented macules on his upper back, on examination of skin scrapings with 10% KOH under microscope spaghetti and meatball appearance was seen, for which Selenium sulfide is indicated as a treatment by the physician. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pityriasis Versicolor or Tinea versicolor is a superficial infection of the skin caused by Malassezia furfur (Pityrosporum orbiculare).
  • COLONY → Yeast like consistency
  • CLINICAL FEATURES: presents with discrete hyperpigmented or hypopigmented macules/scales (Refer to the image below) on chest or upper back.
  1. HIGHER incidence in tropics
  2. PREDISPOSING FACTORS:
  • perspiration
  • corticosteroids
  • malnutrition
  • hereditary
  • Immunosuppression

DIAGNOSIS:

Microscopic Examination of Skin Scrapings:

  • scales + 10% KOH → SPAGHETTI & MEATBALL APPEARANCE (Refer to the image below)
  • scales + Wood lamp → Yellow Fluorescence
  • Scales + SDA & olive oil overlay [Lipophilic fungus] → FRIED EGG COLONIES

Treatment for T. Versicolor:

  • Topical → Selenium sulfide, salicylic acid, a solution containing sulfur, terbinafine cream.
  • Oral → Ketoconazole.

questions.text: A 64 year old man with coronary artery disease and atrial fibrillation comes to the OPD for evaluation of fevers, arthralgias, pleuritis, and malar rash. These symptoms have developed over the past 6 months. The pleuritis has responded to steroid therapy, but prednisone has been unable to be tapered off due to recurrence of symptoms at daily steroid doses <15 mg of prednisone. His medications include aspirin, procainamide, lovastatin, prednisone, and carvedilol. You suspect drug-induced lupus due to procainamide. Antibodies directed against which of the following proteins is most likely to be positive?
questions.solution:
• Drug-induced lupus can occur with a variety of medications and should be considered when individuals present atypically.
  • Drug-induced lupus usually presents with fever, malaise, intense arthralgias/myalgias, serositis, and rash.
  • Discontinuation of the medication usually leads to resolution of the symptoms over a period of weeks, although anti-inflammatory medications may need to be utilized to control symptoms until the inflammation subsides.
  • Common drugs that cause lupus include procainamide, propafenone, hydralazine, propylthiouracil, lithium, phenytoin, carbamazepine, sulfasalazine, and minocycline.
  • Antibody testing usually reveals a positive antinuclear antibody and antihistone antibodies. Antibodies to ds-DNA are rare.
  • Anticardiolipin antibodies are seen in antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, which would present with arterial and venous thromboembolic disease.
  • Anti-RNP antibodies are seen with mixed connective tissue disease that usually presents with features of lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, and/or scleroderma.
  • Anti-ribosomal P antibodies are associated with depression and psychosis with central nervous system involvement of SLE

questions.text: A patient visited the hospital with non-specific symptoms like fever, mild cough, rashes, etc. On further examination and testing, the physician is suspecting it to be an arboviral infection. Which of the following is true regarding arboviral infections?

choices.text: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is caused by inhalation of rodent feces
KFD is caused by the bite of wild animal
Lyssa virus is transmitted by ticks
Yellow fever is transmitted by Anopheles mosquito

questions.solution:
• All the above are false statements except Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is caused by inhalation of rodent feces.

Option 1: Hantaviruses:

  • Found worldwide.
  • Cause two serious and often fatal human diseases:
    • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome
    • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS).
  • Rodents are the reservoirs for hantaviruses.
  • The virus infections in rodents are lifelong and without deleterious effects.
  • Transmission to humans occurs by inhaling aerosols of rodent excreta (urine, feces, saliva).
  • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is generally severe, with reported mortality rates of 30% or greater.
  • The disease begins with fever, headache, and myalgia followed by rapidly progressive pulmonary edema, often leading to severe respiratory compromise.

Option 2, 3: KFD (Kyasanur forest disease) is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected hard ticks.

Option 4: Yellow fever is transmitted by Aedes mosquito.

questions.text: A 29 year old male with a history of episodic abdominal pain ,stress-induced edema of lips and the tongue is likely to have low functional or absolute levels of which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
• The treatment of choice in acute attacks consists of replacement with commercially available Cl inhibitor (C l-IN H) concentrates or kallikrein inhibitor or, if those are unavailable, fresh-frozen plasma. In HAE type III, infusion o f C l-IN H has proven to be ineffective.
  • For prophylaxis, attenuated androgens are the current initial mode of treatment.
  • The drug MC used is danazol, but all attenuated androgens are useful in treatment.
  • Icatibant is a selective bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist approved for use in HAE

questions.text: A 45 year old male is hospitalized in the ICU for postsurgical complications after gastrojejunal bypass surgery for several weeks . He is having persistent fevers and on examination is found to have erythema, fluctuance, and tenderness over the posterior surface of the left elbow. Initial management of this disorder should include all the following except

choices.text: aspiration of the collection for Gram stain and culture
microscopic evaluation of aspirate for crystals

questions.solution:
• This patient has a classic presentation for olecranon bursitis, with warmth, swelling, fluctuance, and tenderness over the posterior aspect of the elbow.
  • Most often this is due to repeated trauma or pressure to the area that can occur through leaning on the elbow or through immobility with continuous pressure. Alternatively, infections, generally with gram-positive organisms, can cause olecranon bursitis, and crystalline disease, especially monosodium urate, can cause this picture. Initial evaluation involves aspiration of the fluid for Gram stain, culture, cell count and differential, and crystal evaluation. Incision and drainage should be reserved for bursitis of infectious etiology that is not responding to antibiotics and repeated aspirations.

questions.text: A 32 year old pregnant woman presents to OPD with thumb and wrist pain which has worsened over the last few weeks. She experiences pain when she pinches her thumb against her other fingers. On physical examination she has mild swelling and tenderness over the radial styloid process, and pain is elicited when she places her thumb in her palm and grasps it with her fingers. A Phalen maneuver is negative. Which condition is most likely?

choices.text: Gouty arthritis of the first metacarpophalangeal joint

questions.solution:
• Inflammation of the abductor pollicis longus and the extensor pollicis brevis at the radial styloid process tendon sheath is known as DeQuervain’s tenosynovitis.
  • Repetitive twisting of the wrist can Cause the condition.
  • Pain starts after grasping the thumb and can extend radially along the wrist to the radial styloid process.
  • Mothers often develop this tenosynovitis by holding their babies with the thumb outstretched.
  • Treatment of DeQuervain’s tenosynovitis includes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and splinting. Glucocorticoid injections can be effective.
  • A Phalen maneuver is used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome and does not elicit pain.
  • The wrists are flexed for 60 s to compress the median nerve to elicit numbness, burning, or tingling.
  • Gouty arthritis will present with an acutely inflamed joint with crystal-laden fluid.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a systemic illness with characteristic joint synovitis and radiographic features

questions.text: True about Corynebacterium diphtheriae are all except:

choices.text: Iron is not required for toxin production
Toxin production is responsible for local reaction
Toxin production is by lysogenic conversion

questions.solution:
• Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender, non-sporing, non-capsulated, non-motile, non-acid fast, gram positive bacilli.
  • C. diphtheriae produces a potent exotoxin encoded by a lysogenic beta-prophage.
  • Responsible for both local and systemic effects.
  • 61,150 daltons ; 2 parts; A: 21,150 & B:40,000;
  • A: active; B: binding
  • Following proteolytic cleavage, the A segment is released into the host cell where it inhibits only mammalian protein synthesis (ribosomal function) via ADP ribosylation of EF-2 which is a tRNA translocase.
  • Inhibition of protein synthesis disrupts normal cellular physiologic functions that are believed to be responsible for the necrotizing and neurotoxic effects of diphtheria toxin.
  • Optimum iron concentration: 0.1 mg/l required for toxin production When treated with formalin the toxoid is formed

questions.text: A 35 year old male came to the OPD with yellowing of eyes. He states that he has had similar episodes of yellow eyes lasting to 3 4 days 10 years ago too. He does not have any nausea, pain in abdomen, dark urine or light-colored stools, itching or any unintentional weight loss. He did not seek prior medical attention because of finances and spontaneous remission of yellowing of eyes. On examination he is mildly obese. On physical examination, abdomen is soft and nontender, and there is no organomegaly. Laboratory examinations show total bilirubin of 3 mg/dL, Direct bilirubin is 0.2 mg/dL. LFT is normal. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Gilbert’s syndrome is characterized by a mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. UGT1A1 activity is typically reduced to 10 to 35% of normal, resulting in impaired conjugation. Diagnosis occurs during young adulthood.
  • Exacerbations occur during times of stress, fatigue, alcohol use, or decreased caloric intake. Episodes are self-limited and benign
  • No treatment is required, and patient reassurance is recommended. Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1 is a congenital disease characterized by more dramatic elevations in bilirubin that occur first in the neonatal period.
  • Medications and toxins may produce jaundice in the setting of cholestasis or hepatocellular injury. Similarly, medications may induce hemolysis; however, the normal hematocrit, LDH, and haptoglobin eliminate hemolysis as a possibility

questions.text: Which drug is used to treat NARST (Nalidixic acid resistant S.typhi)?
questions.solution:
Azithromycin is used to treat NARST (Nalidixic acid resistant S.typhi) among the options given above.

Nalidixic acid-resistance S.typhi (NARST):

  • Surrogate marker of decreased susceptibility to ciprofloxacin.
  • Resistance to nalidixic acid predicts fluoroquinolone failure and can be used to guide antibiotic therapy.

Multidrug resistant typhoid cases: resistant to first line drugs, namely chloramphenicol, cotrimoxazole and ampicillin.

  • Rx :
    • Azithromycin, third-generation cephalosporins.
    • Aztreonam and Imipenem are the potential second line drugs.

MDR-S.typhi :

  • Isolates of S. typhi resistant to chloramphenicol, ampicillin, and cotrimoxazole designated as multidrug-resistant S. typhi [MDR-ST].
  • Ciprofloxacin became the DOC for typhoid fever in patients of all age groups, infected or likely to be infected with fully drug susceptible S. typhi or MDR-ST.
  • Alternative : Third-generation cephalosporins (cefixime for 7 to 14 days or ceftriaxone for 10 to 14 days) and azithromycin (for 7 days).

questions.text: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) may be caused by exogenous factors. Gastrointestinal flora may promote an inflammatory response or may inhibit inflammation. Probiotics have been used to treat IBD. Which of the following organisms has been used in the treatment of IBD?
questions.solution:
• Recent studies have identified a group of genes or polymorphisms that confer risk of IBD. Multiple microbiological agents, including some that reside as “normal” flora, may initiate IBD by triggering an inflammatory response.
  • Anaerobic organisms (e.g., Bacteroides and Clostridium spp.) may be responsible for the induction of inflammation.
  • Other organisms, for unclear reasons, may have the opposite effect. These “probiotic” organisms include Lactobacillus spp., Bifidobacterium spp., Taenia suis and Saccharomyces boulardii.
  • Studies of probiotic therapy in adults and children with IBD have shown potential benefit for reducing disease activity

questions.text: An 84 year old female is brought to the emergency department due to lethargy. At home, she had blood pressure of 85/60 mmHg, heart rate 101 beats/min, temperature 37.8°C. Laboratory data show : sodium 137 meq/L, potassium 2.8 meq/L, HCO3 – 8 meq/L, chloride 117 meq/L, BUN 17 mg/dL, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL. An arterial blood gas shows PaO2 80 mmHg, PCO2 24 mmHg, pH 7.29. Her urine analysis is clear and has a pH of 4.5. What is the acid-base disorder?

choices.text: Non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
• The pH is <7.35, therefore the primary process is an acidosis.
  • The HCO3 – is low and the PCO2 is low, excluding primary respiratory acidosis. The anion gap is normal at 12.
  • The expected PCO2 is between 24 and 16 mmHg for appropriate respiratory compensation.
  • The PCO2 in this example represents normal respiratory compensation for a metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A 57 year old man is admitted to the hospital for dehydration and confusion. In the emergency department he complained of excessive thirst and he was found to have a serum sodium of 162 meq/L and a newly elevated creatinine of 2.2 mg/dL. After receiving IV fluid, his sensorium clears and the patient tells you that he drinks large amounts of fluid each day and makes about 2 L of urine each day. He has noticed that his urine output has no relation to the amount of fluid he drinks. His sodium remains elevated at 150 meq/L, and his urine osmolality returns at 80 mosmol/kg. After appropriate water restriction, you administer 10 µg of desmopressin intranasally and remeasure his urine osmolality. The osmolality is 94 mosmol/kg. Identify the most likely cause of hypernatremia in this patent?
questions.solution:
• The ddx for hypernatremia can be narrow as it causes relative loss of water. Water is lost via the kidney
  • The urine osmolality is a key point
  • If the patient is excreting minimum amt of maximum concentrated urine, GIT eg: osmotic diarrhea, skin or respiratory loss), or remote renal losses (diabetes mellitus) are the cause.
  • He is excreting a large amount of diluted urine. He is not excreting >750 mosms in his urine daily, which would suggest diuretic use.
  • Either central or nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) must be the cause. In this patient, the lack of response to desmopressin indicates nephrogenic DI

questions.text: A 44 year old woman wants treatment for her irregular menstrual cycles associated with heavy menstrual bleeding. In the past 6 months, her cycles have been 22–25 days associated with heavy bleeding which was unusual for her. She hasnt had any significant hot flashes. You suspect perimenopausal disorder and order hormonal testing for the same which is suggestive of the same. You are considering treatment with OCP's to control her symptoms. All of the following would be considered contraindications to use of oral contraceptive pills except

choices.text: prior history of deep venous thrombosis

questions.solution:
• Perimenopause refers to the time period prior to menopause during which menstrual cycles become increasingly irregular and fertility wanes.
  • This period usually lasts for 2–8 years before final menses and menopause.
  • In perimenopause, the interval between menses typically declines by about 3 days because of acceleration of the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.
  • Measurement of hormone levels in the perimenopausal period can be difficult to interpret because hormone levels are “irregularly irregular.”
  • Measurement of follicle-stimulating hormone during the early follicular phase (days 2–5) of the menstrual cycle can rule out perimenopause if the levels are very low, while high levels are suggestive of the perimenopausal state.
  • Perimenopause is generally a hyperestrogenic state, and there is an increased risk of endometrial carcinoma, uterine polyps, and leiomyoma during this period. Because of these risks, low-dose oral contraceptive pills are commonly used during perimenopause.
  • Use of oral contraceptives is also important because the risk of unintended pregnancy in this period rivals that of adolescence. However, the risks of oral contraceptives need to be weighed against the increased risk of thrombosis and breast cancer.
  • Contraindications to the use of oral contraceptives are breast cancer, cigarette smoking, liver disease, history of thromboembolic or cardiovascular disease, or unexplained vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: Building a tower of six cubes by a 24-month-old child requires?

choices.text: able to link actions to solve problems

questions.solution:
Milestones at 2-4 yrs of age:

Age Gross motor Fine motor Language
24 months Walks up and downstairs (2 feet/step)Jumps Tower of 6 blocksDraws vertical and circular strokeTurns the pages of a book one page at a time Puts 3 words together (subject, verb, object)
36 months Rides a tricycle, can steer and pedalAlternate feet going upstairs Can build a tower with 9 blocksCan copy circleCan dress and undress fully Knows full name,age and sex
48 months Hopes on one footAlternate feet going DownstairsThrows ball overhand Copies cross Tells story

Extra Edge:

Developmental Quotient (DQ) = Developmental age/ Chronological age * 100

= 3 yr. / 6 yr. * 100

= 50

questions.text:
A 54 year old lady with a past medical history of a compression fracture of T4 vertebral body comes to the endocrinologist for evaluation of osteoporosis. She is experiencing perimenopausal symptoms like irregular menstrual periods and hot flashes. She is otherwise healthy. A bone mineral density scan demonstrates a T score of –3.5 SD and a Z score of –2.5 SD 
All of the tests are indicated for evaluating osteoporosis except ?

choices.text: follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone levels

questions.solution:
• Osteoporosis is a common disease affecting 8.1 million women and 2 million men in the US. It's MC in postmenopausal women.
  • Estrogen loss causes bone loss by activating bone remodeling sites and that causes exaggerated imbalance between bone formation and resorption.
  • Osteoporosis is usually diagnosed by bone mineral density scan. Osteoporosis is diagnosed when T score is –2.5 SD in the lumbar spine, neck of femur.
  • Other endocrine conditions including hyperthyroidism and hyperparathyroidism should be checked.
  • FSH and LH levels would be elevated but are not useful in this individual as she presents with a known perimenopausal state.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy presented with recurrent eye blinking behavior and recurrent extension of extremities,mother describes the movement as sudden, rapid, and repetitive movements,it was present the nine months. Of the following ,the MOST appropriate diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• A tic is the sudden, rapid, recurrent , non rhythmic motor, movement or vocalization, eye blinking, neck jerking, shoulder shrugging, extension of the extremities.
  • Onset of the tics is typically between ages 4 and 6 yr, in Tourette's disorder both the multiple motor and one or more vocal tics have been present at some time during the illness,may be concurrently for > 1year.
  • ln chronic or persistent tic disorder either one or more motor or vocal tics are present during the course of the disease while in provisional tic disorders the duration is < 1 yr.
  • Chorea is involuntary, random, quick,jerking movements, most often of the proximal extremities, that flow from joint to joint (not in the same manner), movements are abrupt, non-repetitive, and arrhythmic and have variable frequency and intensity

questions.text: A 25 year old female with increasing facial hair and acne for the past 4 months comes to the OPD as she has noticed some deepening of her voice. On Examination, she is having moderate obesity without abdominal striae or bruising. All steps would be important initial steps in the diagnosis except?
questions.solution:
• Hirsutism is defined as an excessive male patterned hair growth. It may represent a variation on the norm or be a prelude to a more serious underlying condition.
  • Virilization is a concerning sign for an ovarian or adrenal cause of excess androgen production.
  • This patient’s change in voice and body habitus heightens one’s concern about a virilizing process.
  • A thorough medication history is indicated because drugs such as phenytoin, minoxidil, and cyclosporine have been associated with androgen-dependent hair growth.
  • Family history is critical as some families have a higher incidence of hirsutism than others do.
  • Androgens are secreted by both the ovaries and the adrenal glands. An elevation in plasma total testosterone above 12 nmol/L usually indicates a virilizing tumor.
  • A basal DHEAS level above 18.5 µmol/L suggests an adrenal source.
  • Therefore, checking both levels is a useful initial hormonal screen in evaluating virilization.
  • Although polycystic ovarian syndrome is by far the most common cause of ovarian androgen excess, initial screening with ultrasound is not recommended.
  • Likewise, females may have an ovarian source of androgen secretion with only slightly enlarged ovaries on ultrasound.
  • Therefore, ultrasound is an insensitive and nonspecific test.

questions.text: A 13 year old adolescent female came to the OPD with complaints of feeling fat especially over stomach area and thighs. She also feels cold, tired,weak,and is lacking energy. Examination shows ,heart rate 46 beats/min,blood pressure70/40mmHg, weight below average , dry skin,and lanugo-type hair growth on face; lab investigation point towards hypokalemia and hypophosphatemia. What will be the MOST appropriate next step is
questions.solution: Heart rate <50 beats/min and blood pressure <80/50 mmHg with hypokalemia and hypophosphatemia are indications for admission in anorexia nervosa; other indications may include hypoglycemia, dehydration, temperature <36.1C, <80% healthy body weight, hepatic, cardiac, or renal compromise, suicidal intent and plan

questions.text: Which of the following therapies have NOT shown to reduce the risk of hip fractures in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis
questions.solution:
• Raloxifene (SERM) is used as treatment for osteoporosis after menopause but it has no role in hot flushes, in fact vasomotor symptoms are increased with use of raloxifene
  • Raloxifene is known to reduce the risk of vertebral fractures by 30 to 50%. There are no data confirming a similar effect on nonvertebral fractures.

questions.text: The Behavioral Changes In attention deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD) should met all the following criteria EXCEPT

choices.text: developmentally inappropriately far comparing with other children of the same age
must be present for at least for 6 mo
must be present in 2 or more settings

questions.solution: EXPLANATION- It is important to systematically gather and evaluate information from a variety of sources, including the child, parents, teachers, physicians, and, when appropriate, other caretakers, over the course of both diagnosis and subsequent management. These behaviors should be evident before age of 12 yr

questions.text: A 23 year old pregnant woman at 24 weeks gestation presents to the ER with pain in her abdomen. Her symptoms started about 7 hours prior to presentation and she has no diarrhea. She has nausea and vomiting. Her pain started from the periumbilical area and is now radiating to the flanks. On examination, Temperature = 100.3°C, BP =129/90 mmHg, HR= 105 beats/ min, P/A there is mild abdominal tenderness. Her os is closed and her obstetric history is fine. Fetal monitoring shows a normal FHR . WBC count is 10,000/µL. Urine analysis shows 2 WBC per high powered field, no epithelial cells, and 1 red blood cell per high powered field. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Appendicitis occurs in every 500–2000 pregnancies and tends to be most common during the second trimester.
  • It is important to consider acute appendicitis in this population due to the frequent occurrence of mild abdominal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting during pregnancy.
  • The unremarkable urine analysis makes pyelonephritis or nephrolithiasis less likely. Rupture of a Graafian follicle (mittelschmerz) occurs during menses, not pregnancy.
  • Fitz-Hugh–Curtis (perihepatitis) syndrome could present with these symptoms during pregnancy; however, there is no cervicitis on examination, and the initial periumbilical pain makes appendicitis more likely

questions.text: A 3 month baby of a keen and highly educated family presented with a history of URTl followed by deterioration of level of consciousness and seizure. CT brain shows intracranial bleeding with no evidence of skull fracture. Fundoscopy was normal. Mother gives a history of difficult labour but with normal development, mild hypotonia, and macrocephaly which was reassured initially by the general Pediatrician. The MOST likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
• Patients with birth trauma may have asymptomatic subdural hematoma which may resolve by the end of the first month of life.
  • Arteriovenous malformation usually has subarachnoid hemorrhage.
  • Encephalitis is a possibility but unusually present with intracranial bleed.
  • The presence of hypotonia and macrocephaly and absence of retinal hemorrhage makes the diagnosis of Glutaric aciduria type 1 is the most likely one

questions.text: A 47 year-old woman has achieved a pregnancy via in vitro fertlization (IVF) using donor eggs from a 21-year-old woman and sperm from her 46- year-old husband. She has a sonogram performed at 6 weeks gestational age that shows a twin pregnancy. A subsequent sonogram at 12 weeks shows a 5-mm nuchal fold is discovered in one of the embryos. What does this imply?

choices.text: The embryo has a high risk of a neural tube defect.
The embryo has a high risk of cardiac malformation.
Such a nuchal fold is normal and there are no implications to the fetus.
The embryo has an abnormal karyotype with the most likely diagnosis of Turner syndrome

questions.solution:
• Nuchal translucency measured between 10 and 13 weeks is a useful marker for increased risk of chromosome abnormalities such as, but not limited to, Down syndrome.
  • The larger the nuchal translucency, the greater the risk of other adverse pregnancy outcomes, including fetal demise, cardiac abnormalities, and other genetic syndromes, even if the karyotype is normal.
  • The nuchal translucency will almost always disappear by 15 weeks; this does not reduce the risk of there being an aneuploid condition, although cystic hygromas in the second trimester are primarily associated with Turner syndrome.
  • In the first trimester, nuchal translucencies most likely indicate Down syndrome, followed by trisomy 18, and then Turner syndrome.

questions.text: Zinc Deficiency Associated With increased risk for all the following EXCEPT
questions.solution: Zinc is most Essential for proper growth and development, and an important catalyst for about 100 specific enzymes

questions.text: A 31 year old G1P0 presents to your office at 22 weeks gestaton seeking a second opinion. She was informed her baby has a birth defect. The ultrasound image is given below. Which is the most likely defect?
questions.solution:
• An encephalocele is an outpouching of the neural tissue through a defect in the skull
  • Hydrocephalus is usually related to the size of the lateral ventricles
  • An omphalocele is a defect in abdominal wall at the insertion of the umbilical cord, which may lead to herniation of the abdominal contents.
  • Anencephaly would mostly require absence of much larger proportion of the skull with diminished neural tissues.
  • A cystic hygroma with which encephalocele can most often be confused on usg, emerges from the base of neck with an intact skull present.
  • Omphaloceles are usually associated with various other birth defects and chromosomal abnormalities.

questions.text: An 8 month old child who was previously well presented with vomiting and an altered conscious level. A CT head reveals significant hydrocephalus with a hyperdense mass. An MRI was arranged and it revealed a lobulated mass adjacent to the trigone of the lateral ventricle. This lesion yields low signal on both T1W and T2W sequences with enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The age of the child and the description of the tumour fit best with a chorid plexus tumour. Another diagnosis that should be considered is Medulloblastoma but that tends to occur in an older age group with peak presentation at 7 years

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD at term with no prenatal care. An ultrasound is performed and shows the fetus to be in the third trimester and to have multiple congenital anomalies, including microcephaly, cardiac anomalies, and growth retardation. Which of the following substances has she abused during her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Chronic alcoholic abuse, causes liver disease, folate deficiency, and many other disorders in a pregnant woman, also can lead to the development of congenital abnormalities in the child.
  • Ethyl alcohol is one of the most potent teratogens known.
  • The chief abnormalities associated with the fetal alcohol syndrome are cardiac anomalies and joint defects.
  • Chronic abuse of alcohol may also be associated with an increased incidence of mental retardation in the children of affected women.
  • Heroin, benzodiazepines, and methadone are not major teratogens.

questions.text: The majority of poisoning in children arise from ingestion, but exposures can also occur via inhalational, dermal, and ocular route. All the following are true about decontamination EXCEPT

choices.text: the goal is to minimize absorption of the toxic substance
decontamination should be routinely employed for every poisoned patient
water should not be used for decontamination after exposure to phosphorus
the efficacy of the intervention decreases with increasing time since exposure

questions.solution: Decontamination should not be routinely done for every poisoned patient. Instead, careful decisions regarding the utility of decontamination should be available for each patient and it includes: consideration of the toxicity and pharmacologic properties of exposure, route of exposure, the time since exposure & the risks vs the benefits of the decontamination method

questions.text: A 25-year-old G1P0 at 37 weeks gestational age comes to the OPD for a routine obstetric (OB) visit. She complains of dizziness, light headedness, and feeling of syncope as and when she tries to lie down. What is the next step of management for this patient ?

choices.text: Monitor for 24 hrs with a Holter monitor to rule out an arrhythmia.
Do an arterial blood gas analysis.
Reassure her and encourage her not to lie flat on her back.

questions.solution:
• As pregnancy advances , the gravid uterus usually compresses the inferior vena cava and decreases venous return to the heart causing a decrease in cardiac output and symptoms of dizziness, lightheadedness, and syncope.
  • This arterial hypotension resulting from IVC compression is AKA supine hypotensive syndrome or inferior vena cava syndrome.
  • Hence, it is not recommended that women remain in the supine position for any prolonged period of time in the later part of pregnancy.
  • When patients describes symptoms of the supine hypotensive syndrome, there is no need to proceed with additional cardiac or pulmonary workup

questions.text:
A 26-year-old G1P0 patient at 34 weeks gestation is being evaluated intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). She has a history of smokingThe Doppler USG studies show that the S/D ratio in the umbilical arteries is much higher compared to her last ultrasound 3 weeks ago also there is now a reverse diastolic flow.
Which of the following is correct statement?

choices.text: The Doppler USG studies indicate that fetus is okay
With advancing gestational age the S/D ratio is supposed to rise.
These Doppler findings are in fact normal in someone who smokes.
The Doppler studies are worrisome and indicate that the fetal status is deteriorating.

questions.solution:
• Simple continuous wave Doppler USG can be used to display flow velocity waveforms as a function of time.
  • With an increased gestational age, in a normal pregnancy there usually an increase in end diastolic flow velocity which is relative to peak systolic velocity, which in turn causes the S/D ratio to decrease with advancing gestation.
  • Whereas An increase in the S/D ratio is a/w increased resistance in placental vasculature as noted in preeclampsia orIUGR.
  • Nicotine and maternal smoking are also known to increase the S/D ratio.
  • In normal twins the S/D ratio mainly falls within the normal range as the singletons.

questions.text: A 28 year old G1P0 presents to OPD at 24 weeks gestational age with right-sided groin pain which is sharp and occurring with movement and exercise. Relief is attained by using a heating pad. On examination, she is healthy and has no fever or chills.What is the most likely etiology of this pain?
questions.solution:
• The patient is giving a classic description of pain in the round ligament .
  • Each ligament extends from the lateral portion of uterus below the oviduct and travels in the fold of the peritoneum going downward to the inguinal canal and then it inserts in the upper portion of the labia majora.
  • During pregnancy, the ligaments stretch as the gravid uterus grows farther out of the pelvis and can thereby cause sharp pains, particularly with sudden movements
  • . Round ligament pain is usually mostly experienced on the rt side due to the dextrorotation of the uterus that commonly occurs in pregnancy.
  • Usually this pain is improved by avoiding sudden movements and by rising and si?ng down slowly.
  • Local heat and analgesics may also help with pain control.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 at 31 weeks gestation with a known placenta previa presents to the hospital with vaginal bleeding. On assessment, she has normal vital signs and the fetal heart rate tracing is 140 beats per minute with accelerations and no decelerations. No uterine contractions are demonstrated on external tocometer. Heavy vaginal bleeding is noted. Which is the best next step in the management of this patient
questions.solution:
• The patient is starting to haemorrhage from a placenta previa, steps should be taken to stabilize the patient and to prepare for possible emergent c- section.
  • The patient isnt contracting, therefore there is no role for tocolysis.
  • In addition, terbutaline shouldnt be used in a patient who is actively bleeding because it is associated with maternal tachycardia and vasodilation.
  • The actively bleeding patient should be resuscitated with IV fluids while blood is being cross matched for possible transfusion.
  • A Foley catheter should be placed as urinary output is needed to know the patient’s volume status.

questions.text: A 72 year old G5P5 presents to comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. Her last checkup was 6 years ago, when she turned 64. She has a history of hypertension for which she takes diuretics. Which is the best vaccination to recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Women aged 65 years old and older should have of the following immunizations:

1) tetanus-diphtheria booster every 10 years

2) influenza virus vaccine annually

3) a one time pneumococcal vaccine.

  • Hepatitis B vaccine is indicated only in individuals at high risk i.e international travelers, iv drug users, and sexual partners, people with occupational exposure to blood or blood products, persons with chronic liver or renal disease, or residents of institutions for the developmentally disabled, and inmates of correctional institutions)
  • Herpes zoster is indicated for women over the age of 65 if not previously immunized

questions.text: A 50-year-old G4P4 presents for her well-woman examination. She had one cesarean delivery followed by three vaginal deliveries. Her menses stopped 1 year ago and she occasionally still has hot flashes. She tells you that about 10 years ago she was treated with a laser conization for carcinoma in situ of her cervix. Since that time, all of her Pap tests have been normal. What recommendation should you make regarding how frequently she should undergo Pap smear testing?
questions.solution:
• Cervical cancer screening should begin at 21 years of age. Cervical cytology screening is usually recommended every 2 years for women aged 21-28 yrs.
  • Women aged 30 years and older with 3 consecutive cervical cytology test results that are negative for intraepithelial lesions and malignancy or test negative for the high-risk subtype of human papilloma virus may be screened every 3 years.
  • Certain risk factors have been associated with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) in observational studies;
  • women with any of the mentioned risk factors may require more frequent cervical cytology screening: HIV infection, immunosuppression (such as transplant patients), in-utero diethylstilbestrol exposure, and women previously treated for moderate to severe cervical dysplasia or cancer of the cervix.
  • In a low risk patient screening may discontinue at age 70.
  • In this patient with a history of carcinoma in situ of the cervix, annual screening would be recommended.

questions.text: At an anganwadi centre, the ASHA worker is demonstrating technique of insertion and teaching about use of barrier contraceptives for women to a group of village women. She explains that the Vaginal diaphragm should be removed
questions.solution:
Vaginal diaphragm

  • After intercourse, the vaginal diaphragm and vault cap should not be removed before 6–8 h of the last act and should not be kept for more than 24 h.
  • Best time to introduce it is from a few minutes to 2 h before the sexual act,
  • Spermicides must be used along with these devices.
  • Contraindications

?-? Prolapse, cystocele, rectocele because accurate fitting is not possible;

?-? Recurrent urinary tract infection and

?-? Allergy to rubber or spermicidal agent.

  • Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) may occur if the diaphragm is left in the vagina for a long periodRef: William’s Textbook of Gynecology, 3E, Pg no: 131

questions.text: A 54 year old woman presents for a routine visit. On examination, there is an enlarged, tender right adnexal mass. You order a pelvic ultrasound as the next step in the patient’s evaluation. Which of the following conditions of the cyst would suggest further evaluation for a possible ovarian malignancy?

choices.text: The presence of a unilocular cyst in one ovary
Papillary vegetations within a cystic ovary
An ovarian cyst with a diameter of 4 cm

questions.solution:
• Most ovarian malignancies are not found until significant spread has occurred; therefore it is not unreasonable to further evaluate patients as soon as there is a suspicion of an ovarian neoplasm.
  • Pelvic ultrasonography, tumor markers and even surgical exploration may be part of the evaluation of a patient with an ovarian mass.
  • Pelvic ultrasound findings of internal ovarian papillary vegetations, ovarian size greater than 10 cm, the presence of as cites, possible ovarian torsion, or solid ovarian lesions are indications for exploratory laparotomy in the postmenopausal patient.

questions.text: The depicted instrument can be used for all of the following procedures except?
questions.solution: Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) Syringe and cannula for first trimester MTP. It can also be used for incomplete or missed abortion up to 12 weeks and also for endometrial biopsy. After 10-12 weeks, the fetal products are large and bony and hence this may have a high chance of retained products if used.

questions.text: Identify:
questions.solution:
The sinusoidal pattern seen in cases:

(1) Fetal Anemia (fetal hemolysis, abruption, ruptured vasa previa, etc)

(2) Severe fetal Asphyxia

(3) Chorio-Amnionitis

(4) Morphine administration to mother

questions.text: Following picture represent which obstetric grips during palpation
questions.solution: Pelvic grip (Fourth Leopold): This examination is done facing the patients feet. 4 fingers of both hands are placed on either side of the midline in the lower pole of the uterus and parallel to the inguinal ligament. The fingers are pressed downwards and backwards in a manner of approximation of finger tips to palpate the part occupying the lower pole of the uterus (presentation). If it is head, the characteristics to note are: (1) precise presenting area (2) attitude and (3) engagement.

questions.text: A 26 year old G0P0 comes to the OPD describing hirsuitism. Her menstrual history is such that her menses started at age 13 were very irregular. Her menses occur every 2-6 months She also complains of acne and is currently seeing a dermatologist for the skin condition. She denies any medical problems. On physical examination, there is less hair around the nipples, the chin, and upper lip. No thyromegaly or temporal balding is noted. Pelvic examination appears normal with no evidence of clitoromegaly. How will you best describe the patients condition?

choices.text: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor of the ovary

questions.solution:
Consequence of Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome

Short Term Consequences

Long Term Consequence

  • Menstrual Dysfunction (Irregular Menses)Q
    • Amenorrhea / Oligomenorrhea
    • Episodic Menometrorrhagia
  • Hyperandrogenism
    • HirsutismQ
    • AcneQ
    • Androgenic Alopecia0
  • Infertility
  • ObesityQ

Insulin Resistance (Acanthosis NigricansQ)

  • Dyslipidemias (Atherogenic Lipoprotein Profile)
    • ↑ LDLQ
    • ↑TGQ
    • ↓Total cholesterol: HDLratioQ
    • ↓ HDLQ
  • Metabolic syndrome - (Characterized by insulin resistance - obesity, androgenic dyslipidemia and hypertension)
  • Obstructive sleep apnea (Related to central obesity and dyslipidemia)
  • Diabetes Mellitus
    • (Women with PCOS are at increased risk of impaired)
    • Glucose tolerance (IGT) and type 2 DM)
  • Cardiovascular Disease
    • (Women with PCOS have greater prevalence of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease infarction)
  • Cancer
    • Endometrial carcinoma (3 fold increased)Q ovarian cancer (suggested first)
    • Women with PCOS are associated with a definite increased risk of Endometrial cancer. An increased risk of ovarian and breast cancer has also been suggested.

questions.text: A 55 year old male, with a severe mental deficiency, is brought in for a checkup. His sister has the same affliction. According to his family history, their parents are deceased but had normal intelligence and no chronic disorders. The man sits as though he is sewing. On obtaining a ferric chloride test on the patient’s urine, the test turns color with aromatic (ring) compounds, including specific amino acids. Green color confirms the diagnosis. Among the amino acids given below, which of the was most likely detected in the patient’s urine?
questions.solution:
• Phenylalanine: has a benzene ring; is an essential amino acid; gets converted to tyrosine by phenylhydroxylase.
  • Phenylhydroxylase: enzyme deficient in phenylketonuria
  • Hence, elevated phenyl- alanine and deficient tyrosine, leading to developmental delays and severe mental retardation.

questions.text: Myoglobin, a globular protein, is the oxygen carrier of muscles. Which one of the following amino acids is likely to be present within the interior of the molecule of such a protein?
questions.solution:
• The structure of myoglobin is that of most water-soluble proteins.
  • Globular proteins, like myoglobin, tend to fold into compact configurations with nonpolar cores.
  • Inside myoglobin: almost exclusively nonpolar, hydrophobic amino acids like valine, leucine, phenyl- alanine, and methionine.
  • Polar hydrophilic residues like arginine, aspartic acid, glutamic acid, and lysine are found on the surface of the water-soluble protein

questions.text: A cyanosis child, who has recently drunk well-water and thus has reduced hemoglobin, can be treated with a soft drink. Hemoglobin’s ability to serve as an effective transporter of oxygen and carbon dioxide between lungs and tissues is explained by which one of the following of its properties?

choices.text: Hb binds proportionately more O2 at low oxygen tension than myoglobin.
α- and β-globin chains of Hb have very different primary structures, than myoglobin.
Hemoglobin uses oxidized ferric iron to bind oxygen, myoglobin uses ferrous.
Hb shows greater changes in secondary and tertiary structures, after oxygen binding, compared to myoglobin

questions.solution:
• Successive binding of O2 atoms to Hb progressively changes the tertiary and quaternary structure to produce cooperative kinetics and a sigmoidal oxygen-binding curve.
  • This does not occur with the subunits of myoglobin despite similar primary and secondary protein structure.

questions.text: Which of the following are products of TAG breakdown and subsequent β-oxidation that may undergo gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
• Lipolysis of triacylglycerols (TAG) gives fatty acids and glycerol.
  • The free glycerol —> transported to the liver —> phosphorylated to glycerol phosphate —> enters glycolysis or gluconeogenesis pathways at the level of dihydroxyacetone phosphate.
  • Acetyl-CoA and propionyl-CoA are produced in the final round of degradation of an odd chain fatty acid.
  • Acetyl-CoA can’t be converted to glucose but propionyl-CoA can.
  • The 3-C carbons of propionyl-CoA enter the citric acid cycle after being converted into succinyl-CoA.
  • Succinyl-CoA can further be converted to oxaloacetate and enter the glycolytic scheme

questions.text: A 16 year old college student presented to the OPD with complaints of becoming flushed and nauseated after his first drink of alcohol. It is learned that this is due to a genetic variation in some Asians and Native Americans that affects metabolism of a metabolite of alcohol. The variably degraded metabolite would be which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Principal pathway for hepatic metabolism of ethanol: oxidation to acetaldehyde in the cytoplasm by alcohol dehydrogenase.
  • Acetaldehyde —> oxidized, mainly by acetaldehyde dehydrogenase within the mitochondrion, to give acetate.
  • The genetic variations of acetaldehyde dehydrogenase cause sensitivity to alcoholic beverages and are extremely common in the affected populations.
  • This serves as an example of enzyme polymorphism

questions.text: Some organic acidemias or fatty acid oxidation disorders will also involve elevated ammonia. This is related to the location of reactions of the urea cycle, which occurs in which one of the following?

choices.text: In the mitochondrial matrix and the cytosol

questions.solution:
• The formation of ammonia, its reaction with CO2 to produce carbamoyl phosphate, and the conversion to citrulline all occur in the mitochondrial matrix.
  • Citrulline diffuses out of the mitochondria, and the resulting formation of urea, all take place in the cytosol.
  • Fatty acid oxidation and some reactions of organic acid degradation also occur in the mitochondria.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 at 31 weeks gestation with a known placenta previa presents to the hospital with vaginal bleeding. On assessment, she has normal vital signs and the fetal heart rate tracing is 140 beats per minute with accelerations and no decelerations. No uterine contractions are demonstrated on external tocometer. Heavy vaginal bleeding is noted. Which is the best next step in the management of this patient
questions.solution:
• The patient is starting to haemorrhage from a placenta previa, steps should be taken to stabilize the patient and to prepare for possible emergent c- section.
  • The patient isnt contracting, therefore there is no role for tocolysis.
  • In addition, terbutaline shouldnt be used in a patient who is actively bleeding because it is associated with maternal tachycardia and vasodilation.
  • The actively bleeding patient should be resuscitated with IV fluids while blood is being cross matched for possible transfusion.
  • A Foley catheter should be placed as urinary output is needed to know the patient’s volume status.
